%no~

Introduction%ha~
       The goals of this translation are as follows. First, it is to make the NT more understandable. The average reader cannot understand the NT, and much of that is because of the philosophies of translations.%nv~
       Second is to bring more detail to the surface. As many nuances in grammar and shades of meaning of words are brought out as possible, preferring to bring this out in the rendered text rather than to economize words.%nv~
       Third is to take produce a translation which is unconstrained traditional constraints. The more popular Bible translations are maintained by large committees and are built upon long traditions, and while this has its advantages, it also has its disadvantages. Since I’m an outsider who has no self-interest and no reputation to lose, I’m in a position to say things many a distinguished professor dare not for those reasons %nv~
       Fourth is to put another NT translation out in the public domain. The hope is to make it easier to disseminate this work, to weaken the landscape of copyright and other intellectual property stakes for what should be the word of God, and—if you’ll excuse the hint of arrogance—to indirectly contribute to other translations by allowing them to copy and paste should they desire.%nv~
Notes%ha~
Translation Method%hb~
       This is a translation, not a paraphrase. I used the UBS Greek New Testament 3%u@r%u@d Edition as the source, supplemented with phone apps and websites. I didn’t use copyrighted translations as a basis, and only referred to one or two now or then for confirmation, a second opinion, for comparison after the fact, or to simply quote. I never copied any copyrighted translations. Since the KJV and ASV are public domain, I referred to them when I was at my wit’s end. I relied on several commentaries and lexicons plus the occasional grammar book. Of course, I had to research specific areas.%nv~
The Usual Markups%hb~
       Verse numbers are all superscripted, along with footnote references. Any of the traditional verse numbers missing from the UBS text were footnoted. As everyone knows, no punctuation or other special formatting was put in the original manuscripts; these all originate in the translation.%nv~
Italics%hb~
       Words in italics are interpolations. Interpolations consist of words, phrases, or even entire sentences which are added which are not derived from a literal translation of the Greek text. What’s deemed an interpolation is not always cut and dry. I did not consider nuances insinuated by a verb tense or some other grammatical construct or by a shade of meaning of a word used in a particular context to be interpolations.%nv~
       Some of the text was radically modified and although the rendered version has interpolations, it was too messy to italicize, especially the places marked liberties taken. These were marked and handled in footnotes.%nv~
       You cannot make sense of the NT without interpolations, as the writers purposely omitted words for the sake of brevity. Or they were just plain sloppy. Sometimes, though, the writers assumed that the readers had certain a background understanding, one which the modern reader doesn’t have. Some of the interpolations I added, especially the longer ones, are obvious additions. Because the aim of this translation is to produce something which is understandable by the average person, such additions are crucial at times.%nv~
       Of course, all interpolations are subjective, and as such are a source of disagreement. The reason why they’re set off in italics is to alert the reader that they are additions and should be received as such. Since I plan to publish both an abridged and a unabridged version, the unabridged will have the interpolations left in but their italics removed (and I never used italics for anything other than an interpolation).%nv~
Footnotes%hb~
       Footnotes are noted with both capital and small letters formatted in superset and enclosed in brackets. The small-letter footnotes are, for the most part, comments on the translation or are short general comments. Capital-letter footnotes are long small-letter comments, are explanations about what some difficult verses and passages mean, or are just random comments about the passage.%nv~
       The footnotes supplement the translation where the translation fails to do justice to the text, or where there’s extra detail which the curious reader may glean: nuances or other shades of meaning that weren’t thoroughly captured in the translation, as it would be too wordy. In the course of this work, I eventually settled on a set of rules for footnoting. %nv~
       I footnote to express uncertainty; to list alternatives when uncertain; to reveal a lack of justice with which even my best intentions can do to the underlying text; to add insight that would otherwise clutter the translation; to give apology for the choices I’ve made.%nv~
       The word or suffixed by a colon is an alternative, and indicates uncertainty as to how something should be translated from Greek into English. The alternative may be an improvement, it many not. The word also is a supplement to what’s in the translation, an alternative rendering. What’s after also should agree with what was translated, and offer a better explanation, more insight, or just help the reader understand what was translated better. Unlike or, also does not convey uncertainty.%nv~
       The word Lit. (short for literally) is what a literal word-for-word translation of the Greek into English would look like. It is the literal wording that the text in the beginning of the footnote was derived from. The literal wording is added for the following reasons. First, so the reader can see the difference between the final translation and what the word-for-word translation would’ve looked like. Though there are several word-for-word translations available, there are times when the such translations are incomplete, inaccurate, or misleading. Second reason to add the literal wording is when the final translation doesn’t do justice to the literal wording, or when I think there may be value in the reader comparing the translation with the literal wording. Third, the literal wording is many times rich in figures of speech, or prose, or some poetic aesthetic and is a shame to deny the curious reader that richness. Fourth, when the footnote addresses some of the finer or more complicated details of the text, many times I must rely on the literal wording and not on the actual translation. Fifth, in the instances where I’m not certain of something, or when the passage is controversial, I’m supplying the curious reader the wherewithal to make the decision for himself. I attempt to convey what the underlying Greek is saying, and sometimes what the experts say about it, what my opinion of this is based on my own understanding of Greek, and do all of these so there reader can be armed with the knowledge he needs to arrive at an informed decision on his own. I often hear Bible teachers give explanations about what a Greek word used in a particular passage means, and many times they’re incomplete or worse flat out incorrect. Taking the usual Greek courses offered in seminaries is not sufficient. Many Greek words change meanings based on context; like any other language, Greek words are paired together; prepositions in any language are idiomatic; short, commonly-used words are some of the most difficult.%nv~
       The capital-letter footnotes are longer notes, notes that explain something which isn’t obvious to one who hasn’t studied the Bible intensely for years. These footnotes therefore fill in the background. The background may consist of cultural or historical background. They give clarification and justification to some of the more irregular renderings too. These are called liberties in the footnotes; if the translation deviates completely from the Greek text, this is a liberty. For example, “go out to the on-ramps and the off-ramps,” part of Matt. 22:8, is a liberty; there were no interstates back then, so there were no on-ramps and off-ramps. The reader will know that. But there are other liberties that he won’t know; these liberties are documented.%nv~
       Whatever collateral damage is racked up in the rendering should be cleaned up in a capital-letter footnote. And from time to time a note is added which will explains difficult or controversial passages.%nv~
       %nv~
Abbreviations%hb~
       
AbbreviationMeaningGk.GreekGTThe Greek Texti.e.In other words…that is to say…put another way.Impl.Implied by the nuances in the GT, by a figure of speech, or by symbolismKJVKing James VersionLit.The GT literally reads…LXXThe SeptuagintNASBNew American Standard BibleNIVNew International Version BibleNTNew TestamentOTOld TestamentRef.Reference; refer to       %nv~
%nv~

The Gospel of Matthew%ha~
       According to church history, Matthew was the first of the four gospels to be written. Apparently, it was commissioned by the Jewish church, those Jews who came to believe in Jesus as the Messiah and continued to hold to their Jewish ways. For this reason it is steeped in Judaism and assumes the reader is familiar with the Judaism of the Old Testament.%nv~
       Matthew, one of the twelve apostles, was a logical choice to write this book since he was an eyewitness to most of Jesus’s ministry, which is the majority of the book. It’s assumed that the parts in which he wasn’t an eye-witness, he interviewed those who lived in Israel who were themselves eyewitnesses of John’s ministry, etc.%nv~
       Church history also says that Matthew was originally written in Hebrew then translated into Gk. The GT has a simplistic and awkward feeling, the same sort you get when you follow subtitles of a foreign movie. It is apparent in the GT that Matthew was not a native Greek speaker. He does not have the command of the language which Paul and Luke have. But one thing is clear: an extensive amount of research went into the Gospel of Matthew.%nv~
       But Matthew is rich in figures of speech, rich in symbolism, and has a Semitic feel to it. This gives it a uniqueness among the NT books. The figures of speech have a richness which is difficult to follow for those not intimately familiar with the Bible and those who can’t see the figures of speech beneath the literal words. The more literal translations, the KJV in particular, preserve the colorful language at the expense of being more difficult to comprehend. In order to make it more comprehensible, much of the rich language has to be abandoned, which is a pity. To complicate matters, Matthew quotes Jesus saying things that cause one to stop and scratch his head for a while.%nv~
       So that these treasures of literature don’t completely fall through the cracks of translation, copious footnotes supplement the rendered text to point to the original, beautiful language. In addition, because Matthew is such a lively book, it merits a more lively translation. If one looks through all the layers of translations, simplicity of language, myriads of OT references, one sees that Jesus was a colorful speaker, much like those simple ministers who can break a congregation out into laughter and a moment later bring them to tears. Of interest, also, is that there are a couple of parables which are told like an ordinary story, no surprises. An interesting story, but one which, part way through, ceases to be an ordinary story and goes off the rail into something bizarre. Examples are the parable of the wheat and the tares (Matth. 13), parable of the vineyard day-laborers (Matt. 20). %nv~
%sb~
Matthew Chapter 1%hb~
%u@1A Genealogical Record of Jesus Christ, Descendent of David and of Abraham:%vt~
%u@2Abraham had Isaac,%vp~
Isaac had Jacob,%vp~
Jacob had Judah and his brothers,%vp~
%u@3Judah had Fares and Zara from Tamar, %vp~
Fares had Hesrom,%vp~
Hesrom had Aram,%vp~
%u@4Aram had Aminadab%vp~
Aminadab had Naasson,%vp~
Naason had Salmon,%vp~
%u@5Salmon & Rahab had Boaz,%vp~
Boaz & Ruth had Obed,%vp~
Obed had Jesse,%vp~
%u@6Jesse had King David,%vp~
David got with Urriah’s wife and had Solomon,%vp~
%u@7Solomon had Rehoboam,%vp~
Rehoboam had Abia,%vp~
Abia had Asaf,%vp~
%u@8Asaf had Jehosaphat,%vp~
Jehosaphat had Jeoram,%vp~
Jeoram had Ozias,%vp~
%u@9Ozias had Jotham,%vp~
Jotham had Ahab,%vp~
Ahab had Hezekiah,%vp~
%u@1%u@0Hezekiah had Manassah,%vp~
Manassah had Amos,%vp~
Amos had Josiah,%vp~
%u@1%u@1Josiah had Jehonias and his brothers while in captivity in Babylon,%vp~
%u@1%u@2After the Babylonian captivity, Jehonias had Salathial,%vp~
Salathial had Zerubabel,%vp~
%u@1%u@3Zerubabel had Abioud,%vp~
Abiod had Eliakim,%vp~
Eliakim had Azor,%vp~
%u@1%u@4Azor had Zadok,%vp~
Zadok had Achim,%vp~
Achim had Eliud,%vp~
%u@1%u@5Eliud had Eleazar,%vp~
Eleazar had Matthan,%vp~
Matthan had Jacob,%vp~
%u@1%u@6Jacob had Joseph, Mary’s husband,%vp~
…and from her was born Jesus, who’s called “the Christ.”%vp~
%si~
          %u@1%u@7In total, there were fourteen generations from Abraham to David; there were fourteen generations from David to the Babylonian captivity; there were fourteen generations from the Babylonian captivity to Jesus.%vn~
%u@1%u@8The Way Jesus’s Birth Was%vt~
      After Mary was engaged but before she was officially married to Joseph—and before she was intimate with him—she found that she was pregnant, and that it was from the Holy Spirit. %u@1%u@9Her husband Joseph, being someone who always did the right thing and not wanting to disgrace Mary, decided to himself that he’d quietly break up with her. %u@2%u@0After he talked himself into doing this—of all things—an angel sent from the Lord appeared to him in a dream and said,%vn~
      “Joseph, you marvelous godsend, don’t be afraid to keep Mary as your wife; what she’s conceived in fact came from the Holy Spirit. %u@2%u@1She’ll give birth to a son, and you’re going to name him ‘Jesus’, since he will indeed deliver the people from their sins.” %u@2%u@2All of this has happened in order to fulfill the prophecy which came through the Prophet Isaiah, which says,%vn~
%si~
%u@2%u@3Check this out! Our virgin here will get pregnant and give birth to a son,%vp~
And they’ll call him Emmanuel (which translated means “God with us”)%vp~
%si~
%u@2%u@4Joseph woke up from the dream and did just as he was told to do by the angel sent from God and kept Mary as his wife %u@2%u@5and didn’t sleep with her until after she’d given birth to the son, whom he named Jesus.%nn~
%sb~
Matthew Chapter 2%hb~
          %u@1Now after Jesus was born in Bethlehem, in the province of Judea, during the days of King Herod, out of nowhere these gurus called “magii” who came from the East and showed up in Jerusalem %u@2going about saying, “Where’s that child-king of the Jews? The fact is, we saw his star while over in the East and came to worship him.”%vn~
          %u@3Hearing about this made King Herod queasy, along with everyone else in Jerusalem. %u@4So he gathered the chief priests and the designated teachers called scribes and quizzed them to find out exactly where the Messiah would be born. %u@5They told him, “In Bethlehem, Judea, since it’s been written about by the Prophet Micah:%vn~
%si~
%u@6”And for you, Bethlehem, Judea, by no means%vp~
Do you come in last place%vp~
In the Judean power rankings;%vp~
For out of you will come a ruler who’ll lead my people Israel”%vp~
%si~
          %u@7Then Herod stealthily summoned the magii and ascertained from them the time of the star’s appearance, %u@8and sent them to Bethlehem telling them, “Go ask around and gather all the facts you can about this child. Then after you find him, come tell me so that I can come and worship him too.” %u@9Having heard this from the king, they went out and—just like that—the same star which they saw back east took the lead in front of them until it reached the place where the child was and then stood still up over that place. %u@1%u@0Seeing what the star had done, they got really excited. %u@1%u@1They went into the house and saw the child with his mother Mary and fell flat on their faces and worshipped him. Then they opened their chests and delivered gifts to him, gold, frankincense, and myrrh. %u@1%u@2And having received a divine instruction given through a dream to not return to Herod but instead to take another way out, they left to go back to their homeland.%vn~
          %u@1%u@3Now after they had departed, just like that an angel appeared in a dream to Joseph telling him, “Get up, grab the child and his mother, and run for your life to Egypt. Stay there until I tell you. Herod, you see, is going about seeking to eliminate the child.” %u@1%u@4So he got up, took the child and his mother, and left for Egypt under the cover of darkness. %u@1%u@5And he stayed there until Herod passed away, in order that the prophet Hosea’s prophecy would be fulfilled, which says, “From out of Egypt I summoned my son.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@6Now when Herod realized that he’d been tricked by the magii, he got really angry and had all the children in Bethlehem and all the surrounding areas eliminated, from two and under, consistent with the time which he’d ascertained from the magii. %u@1%u@7It was then that the prophet Jeremiah’s prophecy was fulfilled, which says,%vn~
%si~
%u@1%u@8A sound was heard in Ramah—%vp~
Weeping and wailing—%vp~
Rachel crying over her children%vp~
And she wasn’t wanting to be comforted,%vp~
Since they’re gone for good%vp~
%si~
          %u@1%u@9After Herod died—just like that—an angel sent from the Lord appeared in a dream to Joseph while in Egypt %u@2%u@0saying,%vn~
      “Get up and take the child and his mother and go to Israel, now that those who’ve been craving to snuff out the child’s life are finally dead.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@1So he got up and took the child and his mother and entered the country of Israel. %u@2%u@2But since he heard that Archelaos had replaced his father as king of Judea, he was afraid to go over there. Getting instructions through a dream, he detoured over to the Galilean area, %u@2%u@3and when he got there, he settled in a city called Nazareth, in order that what the prophets had prophesied would be fulfilled, that he would be considered to be a Nazarene.%vn~
%sb~
Matthew Chapter 3%hb~
          %u@1Now back in those days, John the Baptist appeared on the scene in the Judean countryside %u@2saying, “Straighten up and change your ways, since God’s involvement with mankind (the kingdom of heaven) just got here! %u@3You see, what’s taking place here is the prophecy from Isaiah which says,%vn~
%si~
The sound of shouting in the countryside:%vp~
“Block off the road the Lord will take!%vp~
Barricade the streets he’ll be on!”%u@%vp~
%si~
          %u@4John dressed himself in a camel-hair outfit wrapped in a leather belt, and his diet consisted of grasshoppers and wild honey. %u@5At that time everybody in Jerusalem and Judea and everybody from around the Jordan kept coming out to see him. %u@6And they were one after another being baptized in the Jordan River by him while pouring their hearts out in confessing their sins out loud.%vn~
          %u@7Seeing that many of the Pharisees and Sadducees were showing up at his baptism, he said to them, “You nest of vipers, who convinced you to run for your lives because of the coming wrath? %u@8Have the change in lifestyle which goes hand-in-hand with the commitment to a change in ways. %u@9And while discussing this among yourselves, don’t say, ‘We’re descendants of Abraham.’ Oh yes—I tell you, God is able to turn these stones here into descendants of Abraham. %u@1%u@0The axe is lying next to the tree trunk and is ready to be used: Every tree which isn’t yielding good fruit will be chopped down and tossed into a fire. %u@1%u@1Me—I baptize in water towards the goal of repentance, but the one who’ll come after me is greater than me; I’m not worthy enough to carry him around by the soles of his shoes. But him—he’ll baptize in a fiery manifestation of the Holy Spirit—which words fall short to describe; %u@1%u@2with the winnowing fork in his hand, he’ll clear everything off his threshing floor too. He’ll store his wheat in the silo but will burn up the chaff with a fire that will never be put out.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@3Then Jesus appeared on the scene in the Jordan region, coming from Galilee, to get with John, to be baptized by him. %u@1%u@4But John brushed him off saying, “It’s me who needs to be baptized by you, but you’re approaching me instead?” %u@1%u@5Jesus formulated a reply and said, %r@“%R@L%r@e%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@.%r@ %R@T%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@u%r@b%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@u%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@q%r@u%r@i%r@r%r@e%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@u%r@l%r@f%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@”%r@ He then permitted it. %u@1%u@6While he was being baptized, he came straight up out of the water, and—of all things—the sky opened up, and he saw the Spirit of God coming down like a dove upon him. %u@1%u@7And—of all things—a voice spoke from the sky saying, “This one here is my Beloved Son, and I’m quite pleased with him.”%vn~
%sb~
Matthew Chapter 4%hb~
          %u@1Then Jesus was guided by the Spirit into the countryside to be tempted by the devil. %u@2After fasting for forty days and nights, he finally became hungry, %u@3and the Tempter came by and said,%vn~
      “If your position is indeed Son of God, speak so that these stones become bread.”%vn~
       %u@4But he answered him, %r@“%R@I%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@,%vn~
%si~
%R@M%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@l%r@y%r@,%r@%vp~
%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@”%vp~
%si~
          %u@5So the devil then took him to the holy city, and placed him on the battlements on the temple roof. %u@6He turned and, in continuation, said,%vn~
      “If you’re indeed God’s son, jump off. I mean, it’s written,%vn~
%si~
Where you are concerned,%vp~
He’ll issue orders for His angels to follow.%vp~
They’ll even lift you up by putting you on their hands,%vp~
Lest your foot impact a stone.”%vp~
%si~
          %u@7Jesus declared to him, %r@“%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@g%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@v%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@L%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@p%r@p%r@l%r@y%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@m%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %R@H%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@i%r@l%r@s%r@.%r@’%r@”%vn~
          %u@8So again the devil took him to a really high mountain and shows him all the kingdoms of the world and their glory. %u@9And he said, “All of these I’ll give to you, if you would fall and worship me.” %u@1%u@0Then Jesus, finishing the conversation, said, %r@“%R@D%r@e%r@p%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@,%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@!%r@ %R@I%r@n%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@g%r@a%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@,%vn~
%si~
%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@s%r@h%r@i%r@p%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@L%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@%vp~
%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@f%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@u%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@r%r@v%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %R@H%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@”%vp~
%si~
          %u@1%u@1Then the devil left him, and—then and there—some angels came and attended to him.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2Once he heard that John had been taken into custody, he withdrew to Galilee. %u@1%u@3After leaving Nazareth for good, he took up residence in Capernaum-on-the-Sea in the region of Zebulon and Naphtali, %u@1%u@4so that Isaiah’s prophecy might be fulfilled, which says,%vn~
%si~
%u@1%u@5In the land of Zebulon and in the land of Naphtali%vp~
On the road leading to the sea, on the other side of the Jordan%vp~
In the region of Galilee—%vp~
%u@1%u@6The folk sitting in darkness saw a great light,%vp~
And for the ones sitting in a region %vp~
Where they were under the shadow of death%vp~
A light shined on them%vp~
%si~
%u@1%u@7Starting then, Jesus began to go about and proclaim openly,%nn~
%si~

          %u@1%u@8While sauntering down the Sea of Galilee coastline, he saw two brothers, Simon, whom they call Peter, and Andrew his brother, casting fishing nets into the sea, since they were fishermen. %u@1%u@9He said to them, %r@“%R@B%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@s%r@c%r@i%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %R@I%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@n%r@.%r@” %u@2%u@0Right away they quit being fishermen and became his disciples.%vn~
          %u@2%u@1Continuing on from there, he saw another pair of brothers, James son of Zebedee and John his brother, in the boat with their father Zebedee mending their fishing nets. He called them. %u@2%u@2Right away they left the boat and their father and became his disciples. %u@2%u@3He began to go about the entire region of Galilee teaching in the synagogues and proclaiming the good news of the kingdom and treating%u@ any kind of and all sorts of diseases and any kind of and all sorts of maladies among the people. %u@2%u@4News of him spread throughout the whole region of Syria. They brought to him all kinds of people having something wrong with them…various kinds of sicknesses, those suffering or in pain, the demon-possessed, epileptics, paralytics…and he treated everyone. %u@2%u@5Large crowds from Galilee, Decapolis, Jerusalem, the Jordan, and from the other side of the Jordan followed him around.%vn~
%sb~
Matthew Chapter 5%hb~
          %u@1Now seeing the crowds, he hiked up the mountains, and upon seating himself, his disciples came to him. %u@2He opened his mouth and proceeded to teach them in a long, cohesive sermon:%vn~

          %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%r@”%R@D%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@k%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@n%r@u%r@l%r@l%r@i%r@f%r@y%r@           %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@”%R@D%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@d%r@g%r@e%r@ %r@(%r@i%r@.%r@e%r@.%r@,%r@ %r@d%r@r%r@a%r@w%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@n%r@c%r@l%r@u%r@s%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@           %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@”%R@N%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@‘%R@L%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@,%r@ %R@L%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@’%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@i%r@c%r@i%r@p%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@r%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@l%r@y%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%R@M%r@a%r@n%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@L%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@,%r@ %R@L%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@s%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@h%r@a%r@l%r@f%r@?%r@ %R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@o%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@s%r@?%r@ %R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@o%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@f%r@o%r@r%r@m%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@i%r@r%r@a%r@c%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@?%r@’%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %R@I%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@n%r@f%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@I%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@c%r@q%r@u%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@.%r@ %R@D%r@e%r@p%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@r%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@u%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@’%r@.%r@%vn~
          %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%r@”%R@S%r@o%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@w%r@,%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@i%r@l%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@r%r@o%r@c%r@k%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@R%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@w%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@l%r@e%r@w%r@—%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@g%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@r%r@o%r@c%r@k%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@u%r@p%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@i%r@l%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@R%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@w%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@c%r@r%r@e%r@e%r@k%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@f%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@n%r@k%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@l%r@e%r@w%r@—%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@g%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@e%r@t%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@e%r@c%r@t%r@a%r@c%r@u%r@l%r@a%r@r%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@2%u@8After Jesus finished this sermon, the crowds were just amazed at the way he had taught: %u@2%u@9For he taught in a captivating manner and not like their designated teachers.%vn~
%sb~
Matthew Chapter 8%hb~
          %u@1After he came down out of the mountain, large crowds followed him. %u@2Out of nowhere, a leper came up to him and started groveling in front of him,%vn~
      “Sir, if you so desire, you can clear me up.”%vn~
          %u@3He stretched out his hand and touched him saying, %r@“%R@I%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@s%r@i%r@r%r@e%r@;%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@l%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@”%vn~
Immediately his leprosy cleared up. %u@4Jesus then said to him, %r@“%R@S%r@e%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@r%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@l%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@f%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@m%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@L%r@a%r@w%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@M%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@i%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@b%r@m%r@i%r@s%r@s%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@c%r@e%r@r%r@t%r@i%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@p%r@r%r@o%r@s%r@y%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@i%r@s%r@t%r@s%r@.%r@”%nn~
          %u@5After he entered Capernaum, an army captain came up to him pleading with him,%vn~
          %u@6“Lord, my servant is bedfast, suffering terribly of paralysis.”%vn~
          %u@7On top of the situation, Jesus said, %r@“%R@I%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@8The captain then replied, “Lord, I’m not worthy for you to set foot in my house. Just give the word, and my servant will be healed. %u@9You see, I’m a man who’s used to living under authority, having soldiers under my command. I say to this one ‘Come here!’ and he comes; I tell my servant ‘Do this!’ and he does it.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@0Once he heard this, Jesus was just amazed, and said to his followers, %r@“%R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@I%r@s%r@r%r@a%r@e%r@l%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@u%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%R@I%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@l%r@k%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@d%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@ %R@A%r@b%r@r%r@a%r@h%r@a%r@m%r@,%r@ %R@I%r@s%r@a%r@a%r@c%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %R@J%r@a%r@c%r@o%r@b%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@o%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@n%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@I%r@s%r@r%r@a%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@O%r@u%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %R@D%r@a%r@r%r@k%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@—%r@a%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@n%r@a%r@s%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@3Jesus said to the captain, %r@“%R@G%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@;%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@p%r@p%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@4Jesus entered Peter’s house and saw his mother-in-law bedfast with a high fever. %u@1%u@5He touched her hand and the fever left her. %u@1%u@6When evening arrived, they brought to him many demon-possessed, and he cast the spirits out with a few words, and he treated many who had something wrong with them, %u@1%u@7in order that the Prophet Isaiah’s prophecy would be fulfilled,%vn~
%si~
He himself took our weaknesses%vp~
And bore our diseases%vp~
%si~
          %u@1%u@8Now Jesus, seeing a crowd surrounding him, gave a command to hike up the mountain. %u@1%u@9One of the designated teachers came and said to him,%vn~
      “Teacher, I’ll follow you wherever you happen to go.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@0Jesus, following up the statement, said, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@x%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@i%r@r%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@(%r@i%r@.%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@)%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@2%u@1Another, who was one of his disciples, said, “Let me go from here and bury my father first.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@2Jesus, following up that statement, said, %r@“%R@F%r@o%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@;%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@o%r@w%r@n%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@.%r@”%u@%vn~
          %u@2%u@3Then he got into a boat and his disciples followed him in. %u@2%u@4And—like that—the sea broke into a great commotion, to the extent that the boat was overshadowed by waves. All the while, he was still asleep. %u@2%u@5They came over and roused him from his sleep saying,%vn~
      “Lord—Help! We’re dying here!”%vn~
          %u@2%u@6He said to them, %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@n%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@c%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@t%r@t%r@l%r@e%r@-%r@f%r@a%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@-%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@,%r@”%vn~
He then got up and rebuked the winds and the sea, and a great calm came over the water. %u@2%u@7The men were amazed and said, “Just what kind of guy is this, that even the wind and the sea obey him?”%nn~
          %u@2%u@8After he arrived on the other side, in the Gadarene region, he was accosted by two demon-possessed men coming out of the tombs—really dangerous men—so much so that no one was tough enough to pass through on that road. %u@2%u@9Out of nowhere, they cried out, “We have no beef with you, Son of God—have you come here before the appointed time to torment us?” %u@3%u@0Now off in the distance, a large herd of pigs was feeding. %u@3%u@1The demons begged him, “If you’re going to cast us out, send us into the herd of pigs.” %u@3%u@2He said to them, %r@“%R@P%r@r%r@o%r@c%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@”%r@ So they exited the men, went out and entered the pigs. Like that, the whole herd stampeded over the cliff and into the sea and died in the water. %u@3%u@3All the herdsmen began to flee, and when they got to the city, they spread the word about everything that happened, including what happened to the demon-possessed men. %u@3%u@4Then and there—the whole city came out to meet up with Jesus for the purpose of talking to him, and seeing him, they pleaded with him to leave the area.%vn~
%sb~
Matthew Chapter 9%hb~
          %u@1He got into the boat, crossed over, and arrived at his hometown. %u@2Momentarily, they brought him a paralytic laid up on a cot. Jesus, seeing their faith, said to the paralytic, %r@“%R@C%r@h%r@e%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@3Then and there, some of the designated teachers said among themselves, “This guy’s blaspheming.” %u@4Reading their lips, Jesus said to them, %r@“%R@J%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@c%r@h%r@e%r@w%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@i%r@l%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@s%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@s%r@i%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@’%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@‘%R@G%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@l%r@k%r@’%r@?%r@…%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@o%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@”—He then turns and says to the paralytic, %r@“%R@G%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@c%r@k%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@7So he got up and went back home. %u@8Seeing this, a solemn reverence came over the crowd, and they glorified the God who gives authority such as this to mankind.%vn~
          %u@9Now as Jesus continued on from there, he saw a man sitting at the customs table named Matthew and said, %r@“%R@F%r@o%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@.%r@” And he got up and followed him. %u@1%u@0And when he happened to be lounging at the dinner table, out of nowhere several tax collectors and other kinds of sinners came and joined Jesus and his disciples at the table. %u@1%u@1The Pharisees, seeing this, proceeded to say to his disciples,%vn~
      “Just why does your teacher eat with tax collectors and other kinds of sinners?”%vn~
          %u@1%u@2He heard it and said%r@,%r@ %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@c%r@t%r@o%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@w%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%R@F%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@a%r@n%r@s%r@:%r@ %r@‘%R@I%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@r%r@c%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@c%r@r%r@i%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@.%r@’%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@,%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@m%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@e%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@n%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@4Then John’s disciples came to him, “Just why do we and the Pharisees fast all the time, but your disciples don’t fast?” %u@1%u@5Jesus said, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@g%r@u%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@i%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@.%r@ %R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@N%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@a%r@r%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@-%r@s%r@h%r@r%r@u%r@n%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@a%r@r%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@f%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@l%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@N%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@e%r@s%r@h%r@l%r@y%r@-%r@s%r@q%r@u%r@e%r@e%r@z%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@a%r@p%r@e%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@;%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@w%r@i%r@s%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@u%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@ %R@I%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@a%r@p%r@e%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@k%r@e%r@p%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@a%r@c%r@t%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@8While saying these things, out of nowhere a synagogue head came and began pleading with him saying, “My daughter just passed away—but now, if you come and lay your hand on her, she’ll live again.” %u@1%u@9Jesus and his disciples got up and followed him. %u@2%u@0And, quite abruptly, a woman who had a hemorrhage for twelve years came up behind him and touched the hem of his garment; %u@2%u@1for she kept saying to herself, “If I could just touch his outer garment, I’ll get better.” %u@2%u@2So Jesus turned, looked at her, and said, %r@“%R@C%r@h%r@e%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@,%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@’%r@a%r@m%r@:%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@s%r@c%r@u%r@e%r@.%r@”%r@ And the woman was delivered from her illness that moment.%vn~
          %u@2%u@3After Jesus came to the synagogue head’s house and saw the flute players and the wailing crowd, %u@2%u@4he went among those there saying, %r@“%R@L%r@e%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@.%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@c%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@i%r@r%r@l%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@—%r@s%r@h%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@l%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@.%r@” %u@2%u@5When the crowd was thrown out, he went in and took hold of her hand, and the girl got up. %u@2%u@6And his fame spread throughout the entire surrounding area.%vn~
          %u@2%u@7Continuing on from there, two blind men followed Jesus, crying out, “Have pity on us, you wonderful godsend.” %u@2%u@8Arriving at the house, the blind men approached him, and Jesus said to them, %r@“%R@D%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@?%r@”%r@ They then say to him, “Yes sir.” %u@2%u@9Then he touched their eyes while saying, %r@“%R@I%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@c%r@c%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@a%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@,%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@s%r@s%r@,%r@” %u@3%u@0and they regained their sight. Jesus firmly charged them, “Don’t let anyone know,” %u@3%u@1but they left from there and talked all about it in the entire surrounding area.%vn~
          %u@3%u@2While they were heading out, they brought to him a deaf, demon-possessed man. %u@3%u@3After the demon had been cast out, the deaf man spoke. As the crowd was amazed, the rumor kept on being repeated, “This has never been seen before in Israel.” %u@3%u@4But the Pharisees went around saying, “It’s by means of the head demon that he casts out demons.”%vn~
          %u@3%u@5Jesus went about to all the cities and towns, teaching in the local synagogues and proclaiming the good news of the kingdom and healing all kinds of diseases and all kinds of infirmities. %u@3%u@6Seeing the crowds, he felt deeply sorry for them because they were beaten down and defeated, like sheep that have no shepherd. %u@3%u@7In line with this, he then said to his disciples, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@r%r@v%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@i%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@f%r@e%r@w%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@k%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@S%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@k%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@H%r@a%r@r%r@v%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@ %R@C%r@h%r@i%r@e%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@s%r@p%r@a%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@k%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@r%r@v%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@.%r@”%vn~
%sb~
Matthew Chapter 10%hb~
%u@1…And summoning his twelve disciples, he gave them authority over filthy, disgusting spirits, so that they would cast them out and go about healing all sorts of sicknesses and all sorts of infirmities. %u@2The names of the twelve missionaries are: first and foremost Simon, who’s called Peter, and his brother Andrew; James the son of Zebedee and his brother John; %u@3Phillip and Bartholomew; Thomas and the tax collector Matthew; James the son of Alpheus; Thaddeus; %u@4Simon the Cananaean%u@ (Cananaeans are also called “the Zealots”); and Judas Iscariot, the one who’ll betray him.%nn~
          %u@5Jesus sent out these twelve telling them, %r@“%R@D%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@w%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@r%r@o%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@t%r@r%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@m%r@a%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@c%r@i%r@t%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@;%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%r@r%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@w%r@n%r@-%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@-%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@I%r@s%r@r%r@a%r@e%r@l%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@W%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@c%r@l%r@a%r@i%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@G%r@o%r@d%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@v%r@o%r@l%r@v%r@e%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@(%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@)%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@!%r@’%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@H%r@e%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@a%r@k%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@c%r@k%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@r%r@a%r@i%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@c%r@l%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@r%r@a%r@s%r@s%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@(%r@d%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@s%r@)%r@,%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@c%r@e%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@f%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@f%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@9%R@D%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%R@N%r@o%r@w%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@h%r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@           %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%r@”%R@H%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@w%r@,%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@d%r@i%r@c%r@i%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@c%r@i%r@l%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@f%r@l%r@o%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@y%r@n%r@a%r@g%r@o%r@g%r@u%r@e%r@s%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@f%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@i%r@f%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@           %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@”%R@S%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@f%r@f%r@i%r@r%r@m%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@o%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@,%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@s%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@f%r@f%r@i%r@r%r@m%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@f%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@l%r@y%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@s%r@a%r@v%r@o%r@w%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@o%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@,%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@s%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@n%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@f%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@l%r@y%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%R@D%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@k%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@k%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@h%r@—%r@n%r@o%r@,%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@k%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@k%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@v%r@i%r@o%r@l%r@e%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@I%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@v%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@…%r@%vn~

%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%r@”%R@H%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@t%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@t%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@c%r@r%r@o%r@s%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@t%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@9%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@f%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@r%r@o%r@y%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@f%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@h%r@a%r@l%r@f%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@.%r@%nn~
          %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@0%r@”%R@H%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@c%r@e%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@c%r@e%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%R@H%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@c%r@e%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@c%r@e%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@c%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@d%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@m%r@p%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@c%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ Matthew Chapter 11%hb~
          %u@1When Jesus had finished commissioning his twelve disciples, he went about from there teaching and proclaiming in the neighboring cities. %u@2When John, who was in jail, heard about Jesus’s doings, he sent word to Jesus by way of some of his disciples, %u@3asking,%vn~
      ”Are you the Coming One, or shall we wait for somebody else?”%vn~
          %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%R@J%r@e%r@s%r@u%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@s%r@w%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@p%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@“%R@G%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %R@J%r@o%r@h%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@:%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@g%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@r%r@i%r@p%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@l%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@c%r@l%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@p%r@r%r@o%r@s%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@a%r@f%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@g%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@s%r@u%r@r%r@r%r@e%r@c%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@o%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@c%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@a%r@g%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@s%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@A%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@g%r@a%r@r%r@d%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@7While these disciples were on their way back to John, Jesus began to talk to the crowds about John, %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@t%r@r%r@y%r@s%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@?%r@ %R@A%r@ %r@t%r@w%r@i%r@g%r@ %r@f%r@l%r@u%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@e%r@e%r@z%r@e%r@?%r@—%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@N%r@o%r@.%r@ %R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@?%r@ %R@A%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@c%r@k%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@i%r@t%r@?%r@—%R@L%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@—%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@‘%r@b%r@e%r@a%r@u%r@t%r@i%r@f%r@u%r@l%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@o%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@’%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@i%r@t%r@z%r@y%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@w%r@n%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@9%R@N%r@o%r@,%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@ %R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@—%r@a%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@t%r@?%r@ %R@Y%r@e%r@s%r@—%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@—%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@0%R@H%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@v%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@l%r@k%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@,%r@%vn~

%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%r@”%R@J%r@o%r@h%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@‘%R@H%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@.%r@’%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@9%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@T%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@i%r@m%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@.%r@ %R@H%r@e%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@x%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@l%r@l%r@e%r@c%r@t%r@o%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@n%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@.%r@’%r@ %R@W%r@i%r@s%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@v%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@i%r@c%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@—%r@w%r@i%r@s%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@—%r@b%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@d%r@-%r@r%r@e%r@s%r@u%r@l%r@t%r@.%r@”%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@%nn~
          %u@2%u@0He then began to rip on the cities that had had the most miracles, because they didn’t repent. %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@”%R@B%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@,%r@ %R@C%r@h%r@o%r@r%r@a%r@z%r@i%r@n%r@!%r@ %R@B%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@,%r@ %R@B%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@s%r@a%r@i%r@d%r@a%r@!%r@ %R@B%r@e%r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %R@T%r@y%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %R@S%r@i%r@d%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@i%r@r%r@a%r@c%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@’%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@c%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@g%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@n%r@d%r@u%r@c%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@r%r@l%r@a%r@p%r@-%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@-%r@a%r@s%r@h%r@e%r@s%r@-%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%R@B%r@e%r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@D%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@J%r@u%r@d%r@g%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@s%r@i%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %R@T%r@y%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %R@S%r@i%r@d%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %R@C%r@a%r@p%r@e%r@r%r@n%r@a%r@u%r@m%r@…%r@%vn~

          %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@A%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@i%r@m%r@e%r@,%r@ %R@J%r@e%r@s%r@u%r@s%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@f%r@l%r@e%r@c%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %sb~
Matthew Chapter 12%hb~
          %u@1During that period of time, Jesus walked through the fields on Sabbath days. The disciples were hungry and began to go through and strip kernels off the wheat heads and eat them. %u@2But the Pharisees, seeing what was happening, said to him,%vn~
      “See, look what your disciples are doing. This isn’t allowed on the Sabbath.”%vn~
          %u@3And he said to them, %r@“%R@D%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@D%r@a%r@v%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@—%r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@—%r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@u%r@n%r@g%r@r%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%r@h%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@h%r@o%r@w%r@b%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@b%r@i%r@d%r@d%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@e%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@—%r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@c%r@e%r@p%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@s%r@—%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@t%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@O%r@l%r@d%r@ %R@T%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@m%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@v%r@i%r@o%r@l%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@b%r@b%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@w%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@m%r@p%r@o%r@r%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@m%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@m%r@i%r@l%r@i%r@a%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@a%r@n%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@I%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@r%r@c%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@c%r@r%r@i%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@i%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@f%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@,%r@’%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@m%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@n%r@o%r@c%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@T%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@b%r@b%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@9After he left from there, he went into one of the local synagogues. %u@1%u@0There happened to be a man there with a shriveled-up hand, so they asked him, “Are we allowed to perform healings on the Sabbath?”, in order to find something to accuse him of. %u@1%u@1He answered, %r@“%R@I%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@b%r@b%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@a%r@b%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%R@S%r@o%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@w%r@,%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@m%r@u%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@v%r@a%r@l%r@u%r@a%r@b%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@?%r@—%R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@’%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@u%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@m%r@i%r@s%r@s%r@i%r@b%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@o%r@i%r@c%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@b%r@b%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@.%r@” %u@1%u@3He then turned to the man and said, “Stretch your hand out.” He stretched his hand out, and it was restored to a state of well-being like the other hand. %u@1%u@4After the Pharisees left, they convened a meeting about how they proposed to eliminate him. %vn~
          %u@1%u@5After Jesus made that known, he left from there. Many followed him, and he healed all of them. %u@1%u@6He charged them to not let the word out about him, %u@1%u@7so that Isaiah’s prophecy would be fulfilled,%vn~
%si~
%u@1%u@8Look! My chosen child,%vp~
My beloved in whom My soul is pleased.%vp~
I’ll put My Spirit upon him%vp~
And announce justice to the nations.%vp~
%u@1%u@9He’ll neither squabble nor scream%vp~
Nor will anyone hear his voice in the town square.%vp~
%u@2%u@0He won’t break a damaged twig,%vp~
He won’t extinguish a wick%vp~
Until he brings about a victory for justice,%vp~
%u@2%u@1And those far off will have hope through him.%vp~
%si~
          %u@2%u@2Then they brought to him a blind, mute, demon-possessed man, and he treated him, resulting in the mute man talking and seeing. %u@2%u@3The entire crowd was amazed and was going about saying, ”Isn’t this fellow the marvelous godsend we’ve been waiting for all these years?” %u@2%u@4But when the Pharisees heard about this, they said, “This guy can’t cast out demons except through the help of the demon chief Beelzebub.” %u@2%u@5Knowing what they were really thinking, he said, %r@“%R@E%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@v%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@c%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@v%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@I%r@f%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@v%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@.%r@ %R@S%r@o%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@s%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@l%r@p%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@B%r@e%r@e%r@l%r@z%r@e%r@b%r@u%r@b%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@l%r@p%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@t%r@é%r@g%r@é%r@s%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@f%r@o%r@r%r@m%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@o%r@r%r@c%r@i%r@s%r@m%r@s%r@?%r@ %R@B%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@k%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@ %r@g%r@u%r@y%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@u%r@y%r@?%r@ %R@I%r@f%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@a%r@g%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@l%r@a%r@s%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@l%r@a%r@s%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@H%r@o%r@l%r@y%r@ %R@S%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@           %u@3%u@8Then some of the designated teachers addressed him, and Pharisees too, “Teacher, we want you to perform a spectacular miracle.” %u@3%u@9Jesus replied, %r@“%R@A%r@n%r@           %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@”%R@N%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@i%r@c%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@f%r@t%r@,%r@’%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@t%r@u%r@r%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@o%r@c%r@c%r@u%r@p%r@i%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@w%r@e%r@p%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@l%r@e%r@a%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@i%r@d%r@i%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@I%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@i%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@s%r@—%r@m%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@i%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@s%r@e%r@l%r@f%r@—%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@t%r@t%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@.%r@ %R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@n%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@i%r@g%r@i%r@n%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@.%r@ %R@I%r@t%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@i%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@l%r@l%r@e%r@c%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@b%r@r%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@k%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@4%u@6While he was in the middle of telling the crowds this, his mother and his brothers showed up standing outside wanting to have a word with him. %u@4%u@7Someone told him, “Your mother and your brothers are standing outside wanting to have a word with you.” %u@4%u@8He answered the fellow who told him this, %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@?%r@” %u@4%u@9He put his hand out on his disciples and said, %r@“%R@T%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@—%r@m%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@0%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@c%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@l%r@y%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@%%R@C%r@@%R@H%r@%%R@C%r@@%R@E%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@”%vn~
%sb~
Matthew Chapter 13%hb~
          %u@1About that time, Jesus left his house and took a seat along the seashore. %u@2A large crowd gathered around him, to the extent that he had to get in a boat and cast out a bit and sit there instead, while the crowd stood along the shoreline. %u@3He used a lot of analogies when speaking. As an example he said, %r@“%R@H%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@w%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@w%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@w%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%R@W%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@w%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@i%r@r%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@O%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@,%r@ %r@f%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@o%r@c%r@k%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@u%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@i%r@l%r@.%r@ %R@I%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@q%r@u%r@i%r@c%r@k%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@c%r@k%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@i%r@l%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@n%r@e%r@t%r@r%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@n%r@ %r@r%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@c%r@o%r@r%r@c%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@d%r@g%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@i%r@l%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@h%r@o%r@k%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@f%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@e%r@w%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@u%r@i%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@i%r@e%r@l%r@d%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@3%r@0%r@-%r@t%r@o%r@-%r@1%r@,%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@y%r@i%r@e%r@l%r@d%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@6%r@0%r@-%r@t%r@o%r@-%r@1%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@y%r@i%r@e%r@l%r@d%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@1%r@0%r@0%r@-%r@t%r@o%r@-%r@1%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@9%R@A%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@f%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@i%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@.%r@”%u@%vn~
          %u@1%u@0His disciples approached him and said, “Why do you speak to them in analogies?” %u@1%u@1He answered, %r@“%R@I%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@v%r@o%r@l%r@v%r@e%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@(%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@)%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@g%r@u%r@y%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%R@S%r@o%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@w%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@c%r@q%r@u%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@l%r@y%r@.%r@ %R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@c%r@q%r@u%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%R@I%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@e%r@a%r@k%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@a%r@l%r@o%r@g%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@s%r@o%r@n%r@:%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@‘%r@w%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@’%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@u%r@l%r@f%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@P%r@r%r@o%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@s%r@a%r@i%r@a%r@h%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@%si~
%r@“%R@W%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@%vp~

%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@w%r@%vp~
%r@(%r@i%r@.%r@e%r@.%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@)%r@.%r@%vp~
%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@I%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@o%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@%vp~
