%r@d%r@i%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@r%r@e%r@n%r@g%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@c%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@o%r@r%r@t%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@i%r@m%r@e%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%R@S%r@t%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@c%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@k%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@a%r@y%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@m%r@p%r@t%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@.%r@ %R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@s%r@i%r@r%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@;%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@a%r@k%r@.%r@” %u@4%u@2Again, a second time, he went out to pray saying, %r@“%R@M%r@y%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@p%r@o%r@s%r@s%r@i%r@b%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@s%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@(%r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@k%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@)%r@,%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@t%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@s%r@s%r@.%r@” %u@4%u@3He came again and found them sleeping, as their eyelids had grown heavy. %u@4%u@4Leaving them again, he went out to pray, saying the same thing for the third time. %u@4%u@5Then he went to his disciples and, continuing to engage them, said, %r@“%R@H%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@s%r@l%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@i%r@m%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@?%r@…%R@S%r@e%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@w%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@r%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@t%r@r%r@a%r@y%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@n%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@—%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@G%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@,%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@!%r@—%R@L%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@!%r@ %R@M%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@t%r@r%r@a%r@y%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@r%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@d%r@!%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@4%u@7While he was still speaking, at once Judas, one of the Twelve, arrived with a large crowd, with swords and clubs, sent from the high priest and the councilmen. %u@4%u@8His betrayer arranged ahead of time for there to be a signal saying, “Whomever I kiss, he’s the one; seize him.” %u@4%u@9He went straight over to Jesus and said, “Delighted to see you, Teacher!”, and kissed him cordially” %u@5%u@0Jesus said to him, %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@o%r@?%r@” They then went over and laid their hands on Jesus and apprehended him.%vn~
          %u@5%u@1And, like that, one of the people who were with Jesus drew his sword and struck the high priest’s slave, slicing his ear off. %u@5%u@2Then Jesus said to him, %r@“%R@P%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@w%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@c%r@k%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@l%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@;%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@r%r@a%r@w%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@s%r@w%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@s%r@w%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%R@O%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@p%r@p%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@i%r@l%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@k%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@r%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %R@H%r@e%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@p%r@o%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@w%r@e%r@l%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@g%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@g%r@e%r@l%r@s%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%R@S%r@o%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@w%r@,%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@v%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@O%r@l%r@d%r@ %R@T%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@u%r@l%r@f%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@u%r@r%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@?%r@” %u@5%u@5At that hour Jesus said to the crowd, %r@“%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@p%r@p%r@r%r@e%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@s%r@w%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@l%r@u%r@b%r@s%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@r%r@n%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@u%r@g%r@.%r@ %R@D%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@f%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@y%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@t%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@m%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@a%r@c%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@i%r@z%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@A%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@p%r@p%r@e%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@O%r@l%r@d%r@ %R@T%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@c%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@u%r@l%r@f%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@” Then all the disciples abandoned him and began to flee.%vn~
          %u@5%u@7They took Jesus into custody and led him to the high priest Caiaphas, where the designated teachers and councilmen had gathered. %u@5%u@8Peter followed him at a distance all the way to the high priest’s courtyard and entered it and sat with the attendants in order to see how things would turn out. %u@5%u@9The high priests and the entire Council were trying to find those who would give false, compelling testimony under oath against Jesus, so that they could have him killed, %u@6%u@0and, while many were stepping forward and saying phony things in court, they couldn’t find any. But finally two came forward %u@6%u@1and said, ”This is the guy who said, ‘I can tear down God’s temple and build it back up in three days’ time’.” %u@6%u@2The high priest stood up and said to him, “You have nothing to say in response?” %u@6%u@3But Jesus kept silent. The high priest said to him, “For the love of God, I charge you to testify here before us if you are the Messiah, the Christ, the Son of God.” %u@6%u@4Jesus, in full awareness, told them, %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@ %R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %R@I%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@:%r@ %R@F%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@r%r@o%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@-%r@p%r@o%r@w%r@e%r@r%r@f%r@u%r@l%r@ %r@r%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@-%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@l%r@o%r@u%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@k%r@y%r@’%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@6%u@5Then the high priest got unglued and in a rage starting breaking things, all the while saying, “He just blasphemed! Why do we need to hear any more testimony? You all heard him blaspheme here! %u@6%u@6What have you decided?” They replied, “We sentence him to death.” %u@6%u@7They then spat in his face and beat him. They slapped him while %u@6%u@8saying, “Prophesy for us, Messiah: who slapped you?”%vn~
          %u@6%u@9Now Peter was sitting outside in the courtyard. One of the teen servant-girls went up to him and said, “Weren’t you with Jesus of Galilee too?” %u@7%u@0He denied it in front of everyone saying, “I don’t know what you’re talking about.” %u@7%u@1After he left through the entrance gate, another servant girl saw him and told those nearby, “This fellow was with Jesus of Nazareth.” %u@7%u@2Again he denied it, swearing, “I don’t know the man.” %u@7%u@3A little while later, those who were standing nearby confronted Peter, “Seriously—you too are one of them, since you too talk with the same accent.” %u@7%u@4Then he began to cuss and swear up and down, “I don’t know the man.” Immediately a rooster crowed. %u@7%u@5And Peter remembered what Jesus had said, that before a rooster sounded off he would deny him three times, and he left that place weeping bitterly.%vn~
%sb~
Matthew Chapter 27%hb~
          %u@1At the break of day, all of the high priests and the councilmen met in a council that was convened against Jesus in order to have him killed. %u@2They tied him up, transferred him to the governor Pilate, and thereby placed him in his custody.%vn~
          %u@3Then the traitor Judas, seeing that he was condemned, changed his mind and returned the thirty coins to the high priests and the councilmen %u@4saying, “It’s a sin to betray the blood of an innocent man.” They said, “What do we care? That’s your problem.” %u@5He tossed the money into the collection box for the temple fund, departed, and went out and hung himself. %u@6The chief priests took the money and said, “We’re not allowed to put this into the temple fund, since it’s a blood payment.” %u@7They had a meeting over it, took the money, and bought the potter’s field with it, to be used as a graveyard for foreigners. %u@8For this reason, that field’s called the Blood Field nowadays. %u@9Only then was the Prophet Jeremiah’s prophecy fulfilled, which says,%vn~
%si~
And they took the thirty-coin payment%vp~
The price that had been paid by the ultimate Israelites%vp~
%u@1%u@0And they paid for the potter’s field%vp~
According to the arrangements made by my Lord%vp~
%si~
          %u@1%u@1Now Jesus was made to appear before the governor, and the governor, in his inquisition, asked him, “Are you the king of the Jews?” Jesus answered, %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@.%r@” %u@1%u@2He made no defense against the accusations put forth by the chief priests and councilmen. %u@1%u@3Then Pilate, continuing with the questioning, said to him, “Don’t you hear how severe the charges are that they’re accusing you of?” %u@1%u@4He wouldn’t say a word in reply; as a result, the governor was stupefied.%vn~
          %u@1%u@5According to a holiday custom, the governor would release one prisoner, any prisoner that the crowd wanted. %u@1%u@6At that time they had interned a notorious prisoner named Barabbas. %u@1%u@7While they were conferring amongst themselves, Pilate took the opportunity to say to them, “Who do you want me to set free, Barabbas or Jesus, who’s called the Messiah?”, %u@1%u@8since he knew that it was because of their jealousy that they’d handed him over to him. %u@1%u@9While he was there presiding as judge, his wife sent him word saying, “Don’t get mixed up with that do-gooder, since I’ve been really upset all day because of a dream I had about him.” %u@2%u@0But the chief priests and the councilmen persuaded the crowd to ask for Barabbas, so that Jesus would be disposed of. %u@2%u@1Having considered the matter, the governor said to them,%vn~
      “Which of these two do you want me to set free?”%vn~
      They said, “Barabbas!”%vn~
          %u@2%u@2Not quitting, Pilate said, “What shall I do then with Jesus, who’s called the Messiah?” %vn~
      But making no difference, they all said, “Let him be crucified!”%vn~
          %u@2%u@3He said, “Just what has he done wrong?”%vn~
      But they began to yell louder and louder, “Let him be crucified!”%vn~
%u@2%u@4Seeing that nothing was helping, but instead a riot was forming, he took some water and washed his hands in it in front of the crowd saying, “Don’t blame me for this man’s blood; it’s your problem%u@ now.” %u@2%u@5And everyone in the crowd responded, “Let the blame fall on us and our children!” %u@2%u@6Then he set Barabbas free, but he flogged Jesus and handed him over to be crucified.%nn~
          %u@2%u@7Then the governor’s soldiers took Jesus to where the governor’s palace guard assembled, and the entire unit of guards descended on him. %u@2%u@8They stripped his clothes from him and put a red soldier’s cloak around him, %u@2%u@9and they wove a crown of thorns and placed it on his head and put a stick in his right hand, and they got down on their knees in front of him and toyed with him saying, “Delighted to see you, King of the Jews.” %u@3%u@0They spat on him and took the stick and began to hit his head. %u@3%u@1When they were finished making fun of him, they took the cloak off him, put his clothes back on him, and led him forth to crucifixion.%vn~
          %u@3%u@2While heading out, they found a man from Cyrene named Simon, and they conscripted this fellow to bear his cross. %u@3%u@3Having arrived at a place called Golgotha, which is called the Skull Place, %u@3%u@4they gave him wine mixed with a bitter spice to drink, and when he tasted it, he didn’t want to drink any more of it. %u@3%u@5So they crucified him, rolled dice to divvy up his clothes, %u@3%u@6took a seat, and proceeded to keep track of him there. %u@3%u@7They put a sign indicating the reason for his crucifixion over his head which read, “This is Jesus, King of the Jews.” %u@3%u@8At that time, there were two thugs crucified with him, one to the right of him and one to the left of him. %u@3%u@9Those who came by reviled him, nodding their heads back and forth %u@4%u@0and saying, “The one who’ll supposedly destroy the temple and rebuild it in three days…Save yourself, if you’re God’s son…Let him come down from the cross.” %u@4%u@1In the same way, the chief priests, along with the designated teachers and the Pharisees, taunted him saying over and over, %u@4%u@2”He rescued others but he can’t rescue himself…So, he’s the King of Israel…Let’s see him come down from the cross now, and we’ll believe in him…%u@4%u@3He placed his trust in God; let Him rescue him now if He wants him, since he said that he’s God’s son.” %u@4%u@4Likewise, the thugs who were selected to be crucified with him insulted him.%vn~
          %u@4%u@5Starting at noon, darkness came over the whole earth, lasting until three in the afternoon. %u@4%u@6Around three, Jesus cried out in a loud voice, %r@“%R@E%r@l%r@i%r@,%r@ %R@E%r@l%r@i%r@,%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@m%r@a%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@b%r@a%r@c%r@h%r@t%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@i%r@?%r@”, which is, %r@“%R@M%r@y%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@s%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@?%r@”%r@ %u@4%u@7Some who were standing there and who heard it were saying over and over, “He’s calling for Elijah.” %u@4%u@8Immediately, one of them ran and fetched a sponge fully soaked with vinegar wine, put it on a stick, and gave it to him to drink. %u@4%u@9The rest of the people there proceeded to say, “Let’s see if Elijah comes and saves him.” %u@5%u@0Again Jesus cried out in a loud voice and gave up the ghost. %u@5%u@1And—just like that—the temple curtain was torn in two from top to bottom, the rocks were shaken, %u@5%u@2and the tombs were opened up and many faithful believers who had died were resurrected, %u@5%u@3and with his resurrection left the tombs and went into the holy city and appeared to lots of people. %u@5%u@4The captain of the guard and those who were keeping track of Jesus with him, seeing the earthquake and all the things that had happened, became really frightened, saying, “This guy really was the embodiment of a son of God.” %u@5%u@5Now there were many women there who came to watch the affair from a distance, some of whom had been Jesus’s followers from the Galilean days, attending to him. %u@5%u@6Among them was Mary Magdalene, James’s and Joseph’s mother Mary, and the mother of the sons of Zebedee.%vn~
          %u@5%u@7At sunset a rich man from Arimathea named Joseph, who himself had also been discipled by Jesus—%u@5%u@8This fellow approached Pilate and asked for Jesus’s body. Pilate then ordered for it to be given away. %u@5%u@9Joseph took the body and wrapped it in clean linen, %u@6%u@0placed it in his newly-made tomb, which had been hewn into the rock, rolled a huge stone over to the tomb’s entrance, and left. %u@6%u@1Now, Mary Magdalene and the other Mary sat down across from the tomb.%vn~
          %u@6%u@2That night, which is a day of preparation for the festival, the chief priests and the Pharisees got together and went to Pilate %u@6%u@3and said, “Sir, we remember what that grifter said while he was still alive, that he would be resurrected after three days. %u@6%u@4Therefore, give the order that the tomb be kept secure under guard from now until the third day comes, lest his disciples come and steal his body%u@ and tell the people, “He rose from the dead”; a final such deception would be worse than any deceiving he did before.” %u@6%u@5Pilate said to them, “You’ll get your guard; go out and secure it the best you know how.” %u@6%u@6So they went and secured the tomb, having fortified the rock as it stood against the entrance.%vn~
%sb~
Matthew Chapter 28%hb~
          %u@1After the back-to-back Sabbaths had ended, at the first light of day on Sunday, Mary Magdalene and the other Mary came to take a look at the tomb. %u@2Wouldn’t you know—a huge convulsion had occurred; in fact, an angel sent from the Lord descended from out of the sky, went over to the stone, rolled it away, and sat down on top of it. %u@3His appearance resembled lightning, and his outerwear was as white as snow. %u@4Terrified of him, those keeping guard trembled violently until finally becoming as stiff as the dead, laid out on the ground. %u@5The angel summed the situation up and said to the women, “Don’t be afraid, since I know that you’re looking for Jesus, the one who was crucified. %u@6He’s not here, since he was resurrected just like he said he would be: go look at the place where he was laid to rest. %u@7And—quickly now—go tell his disciples that he’s been resurrected from the dead, and in the meantime he’ll be heading out to Galilee ahead of you; you’ll see him there.”%vn~
          %u@8Quickly, and in a state of great fear and joy, they left the tomb and raced to tell his disciples. %u@9And out of nowhere, Jesus interrupted them saying, “Delighted to see you” They went to him and grabbed ahold of his feet, having prostrated themselves in worship before him. %u@1%u@0Then Jesus, getting to the point, said to them, %r@“%R@D%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@f%r@r%r@a%r@i%r@d%r@.%r@ %R@C%r@o%r@n%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@u%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@n%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@r%r@a%r@d%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@o%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %R@G%r@a%r@l%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@1While they were on their way, another thing was afoot—some of the guards went into the city to tell the chief priests everything that had happened. %u@1%u@2They gathered the councilmen and met with them, and then they got a sizeable amount of cash to give to the soldiers %u@1%u@3saying, “Say that his disciples came during the night and stole him while you were sleeping. %u@1%u@4If this gets reported to the governor, we personally will smooth things over with him and fix it so that you won’t have anything to worry about.” %u@1%u@5They took the cash and did as they were coached to do. And this account has been circulated among the Jews until the present day.%vn~
          %u@1%u@6The eleven disciples went to Galilee, to the mountain which Jesus told them to go to, %u@1%u@7and when they saw him, they bowed before him in worship—but they just couldn’t believe it. %u@1%u@8Jesus came over to them and had a talk with them, %r@“%R@A%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@o%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@9%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@f%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@s%r@c%r@i%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@o%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@l%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@p%r@t%r@i%r@z%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@H%r@o%r@l%r@y%r@ %R@S%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@0%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@r%r@u%r@c%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@b%r@s%r@e%r@r%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@i%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@m%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@.%r@ %R@A%r@n%r@d%r@—%r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@—%R@I%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@o%r@n%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@t%r@i%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@e%r@s%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@r%r@a%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@a%r@p%r@p%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@.%r@”%vn~
The Gospel of Mark%ha~
       According to church tradition, Mark is the one referred to as John-Mark, son of Mary, in Acts 15:37, to whose house Peter went after the angel freed him from the prison in Jerusalem. John-Mark is also the cousin of Barnabas. Some believe that his mother Mary is the one who furnished the upper room used for the Last Supper and also used on the day of Pentecost. Some believe that the “young man” whom Mark refers to in Mark 14:51,52 is none other than himself, corroborating the theories. But most agree that the “Mark my son” whom Peter refers to in 1 Pet. 5:13 is the same John-Mark and is the author of the Gospel of Mark.%nv~
       Mark was not actually Peter’s son, but he was a close enough companion and brother that Peter claims him as his figurative son, not only a son in the faith but a son in relation. Church tradition says that Mark was Peter’s interpreter, likely interpreting Aramaic into Greek as Peter itinerated throughout the Roman Empire. Serving as Peter’s interpreter, Mark would re-tell the same stories over and over again. He also spent a lot of time with Peter, everything from travelling to dining. No doubt, Mark spoke to Peter a lot and asked many questions about the missing details of the life of Jesus.%nv~
       Also according to church tradition, Peter was martyred in Rome. Mark was there at that time, and the brethren asked him to commit all of what Peter had told him over the years to a book. This book is the Gospel of Mark. Mark’s gospel is written to a Roman audience, so it does not dwell on things that would be interesting to a Jewish believer of the day who believed in the Messiah. Mark’s gospel is full of drama, action, encounters, confrontation. The teachings it contains are more down-to-earth than Matthew or Luke, though they are wrapped in analogy (parable) as Jesus taught them.%nv~
       Mark’s Greek is simple. He does not have the command of the language that Luke and Paul do, and his Gospel makes repeated use of simple words rather than drawing on less common, more specific words. There’s rich detail in the description of characters that looks like it came straight from the mouth of Peter. It vividly paints a familiarity with the character. For example, the story of the woman with the hemorrhage, which begins in Mark 5:25. The details give us a clear picture of this woman’s ordeal:%nv~
       A woman who had a hemorrhage for twelve years, having suffered a great deal at the hands of many doctors, spending everything she had—and nothing was helping but instead things were trending more to the worse…%ni~
       The details about the length of her affliction and how she had spent everything she had trying to find a cure leaves a stronger impression than if Mark had simply wrote, “there was a woman who had a really bad hemorrhage…”%nv~
       Another example comes from the story of Herod and John the Baptist. Herod kept John locked up in jail, and with detail Mark supplies about Herod (Mark 6:19,20), one acquires a familiarity with Herod:%nv~
       So Herodias maintained a grudge against him and was wanting to kill him, and wasn’t yet able to do so, since, throughout, Herod had a reverential awe of John, knowing him to be an upstanding man, right in the eyes of God and holy, and was keeping him safe. After listening to him many times, he became conflicted, yet still enjoyed listening to him.%ni~
       …the story continues after Herod’s stepdaughter finishes her dance. The silly girl “rejoined the party with hasty eagerness”; one can feel the glee coursing through her cruel, juvenile head.%nv~
       He swore up and down to her multiple times, “Whatever you ask me for, I’ll give it to you—anything you want—anything at all.” She excused herself and said to her mother, “What should I ask for?” Her mother said, “John the Baptist’s head.” Straightaway she rejoined the party and with hasty eagerness said, “I want you to give me John the Baptist’s head on a platter—right now.”%ni~
       On the other hand, Mark is loud, clumsy, and careless as a writer, in spite of apparently having a scribe work with him to proof-read his Greek and to translate words for obscure objects and the like. In spite of his simple use of Greek, the translator must pause and think what Mark meant to say. He over-uses the imperfect and present subjunctive tenses for effect. He uses and when he should use or and vice-versa (ex: Mark 11:28). He gets some simple events out of sequence, like Mark 12:8, where it literally reads, “They took him, killed him, and drove him outside of the vineyard.” As correlated with Matt. 21:39, he means, “They took him, drove him some place outside of the vineyard, and killed him there.” In other words, they first drove him out of the vineyard then killed him, not the other way around.%nv~
       Modern criticism asserts that Mark wrote his Gospel first, then it became the basis for Matthew and Luke. The critics are quick to dismiss reports from early church witnesses who contradict this theory, and are slow to propose theories of how the commonality could have come about.%nv~
       Another point of contention is the ending of Mark’s gospel, Mark 16:9–20. A footnote in a contemporary translation such as the NASB states that this ending is missing from two of the oldest manuscripts. Modern critics claim that the ending of Mark has been lost for all time, seizing upon this in their eagerness to poke holes in the integrity of the Scriptures. We do not have the detail of information we would like to solve this mystery, however there are enough fragments scattered over time to postulate a likely scenario. This is analogous to how the NTSB determines causes of crashes in smaller aircraft: they sift through the evidence and eliminate possibilities until they’re left with the “likely” cause of the crash. They cannot say with absolute certainty what caused the crash, but they can state with confidence what likely caused the accident.%nv~
       In this train of thought, the mystery of the ending of Mark is likely explained in this way: the ending was intentionally truncated from certain manuscripts in the late third or early fourth centuries by order of one in authority, perhaps even Eusebius of Caesarea himself. The reason this person did so was because he refused to believe what was written in Mark 16:16-19. Ironically, these manuscripts, which are called the Alexandrian text-type, are the most accurate in most every other respect to the originals, as the editors who produced them made a concerted effort to eradicate the false emendations (mostly insertions) which had accumulated over time in manuscripts everywhere, most likely in the second and third centuries, and they predate any false changes made in the fourth century and onwards. To a large extent, scholars in the 19%u@t%u@h and 20%u@t%u@h centuries, observing the faithfulness and accuracy of the hand of correction which guided the Alexandrian manuscripts, could not fathom that the same party who had corrected so many verses in the NT would be the one most instrumental in trashing the largest and most important disputed passage in the NT—but this is precisely what they did.%nv~
%sb~
Mark Chapter 1%hb~
%u@1The Beginning of the Good News of Jesus Christ, Son of God%vt~
%u@2…Just as it had been written by the Prophet Isaiah:%nn~
%si~
      See here—I will send my messenger%vn~
      To where your attention is fixated,%vn~
      Who’ll prepare your way%vn~
%si~
          %u@3The sound of shouting in the countryside:%vn~
“Block off the road the Lord will take!%vp~
      Barricade the streets he’ll be on!”%u@%vn~
%si~
          %u@4John the Baptist came on the scene in the countryside preaching a baptism—a water immersion-type of initiation ceremony—signifying a total commitment to a change in conduct to live the right way and signifying an initiation into a forgiveness of sins. %u@5All of the Judean region and everyone in Jerusalem were coming out and were being baptized by him in the Jordan River, one after another, while pouring their hearts out in confessing their sins out loud. %u@6John dressed himself in a camel hair outfit wrapped in a leather belt and for food ate grasshoppers and wild honey. %u@7He preached, “One’s coming after me who’s greater than me, for whom I’m not worthy of bending over and unfastening one of the straps on his sandals. %u@8Me—I baptize in water, but he—he’ll baptize you in the Holy Spirit.”%vn~
          %u@9Jesus of Nazareth, Galilee came on the scene in those days and was baptized by John. %u@1%u@0As he came straight up out of the water, he saw the sky parting and the Spirit descending upon him like a dove. %u@1%u@1A voice spoke from out of the sky, “You are my Beloved Son. I’m quite pleased with you.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@2Immediately the Spirit drove him into the countryside. %u@1%u@3He was out there in the middle of nowhere for forty days, being tempted by Satan. He was fighting for his life, and all the while the angels were attending to him.%vn~
          %u@1%u@4After John had been taken into custody, Jesus came to Galilee preaching God’s message of good news, %u@1%u@5and saying that the time had arrived and that God’s involvement with you (God’s kingdom) had drawn near; and saying, %r@“%R@G%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@c%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@g%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@v%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@o%r@d%r@ %R@N%r@e%r@w%r@s%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@6While passing by the Sea of Galilee, he saw Simon and his brother Andrew casting a net, seeing that they were fishermen. %u@1%u@7Jesus said to them, %r@“%R@C%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %R@I%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@n%r@.%r@” %u@1%u@8Right away they left their nets and followed him. %u@1%u@9He continued onwards a bit further and saw James, son of Zebedee, and his brother John, while they were in the boat mending the nets. %u@2%u@0Right away he called out to them, and they left their father Zebedee in the boat with the hired hands and departed to be his followers.%vn~
          %u@2%u@1They came to Capernaum, and without delay he started teaching in the synagogue there on the Sabbaths. %u@2%u@2They were amazed at his teaching, since he was teaching in a captivating manner, and not like their designated teachers, the Scribes. %u@2%u@3In an instant, there was a man right there in their synagogue with a demonic spirit, and he screamed, %u@2%u@4”We have no beef with you, Jesus of Nazareth; did you come to annihilate us? I know who you are: you’re the Holy One of God.” %u@2%u@5Jesus sternly took charge over him saying, %r@“%R@S%r@h%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@!%r@”%r@ %u@2%u@6The demonic spirit shook him real good, cried out in a loud voice, and then exited him. %u@2%u@7Everyone was amazed, to the extent that they began to discuss and argue among themselves, “Just who is this guy?…Fresh teaching delivered in a captivating manner…He even takes charge over demonic spirits, and they obey him.” %u@2%u@8Immediately, the news about him spread to everyone in the entire area surrounding Galilee.%vn~
          %u@2%u@9Right after leaving the synagogue, they went with James and John to Simon and Andrew’s house. %u@3%u@0Simon’s mother-in-law was laid out with a fever, and immediately they spoke to Jesus about her. %u@3%u@1He went over to her, took her hand, pulled her up, and the fever left, and she began to attend to their needs. %u@3%u@2When it was late in the day and the sun was setting, they began to bring him all those having something wrong with them and the demon-possessed. %u@3%u@3The whole city gathered at the door, %u@3%u@4and he healed many of those who had something wrong with them consisting of a disease of one kind or another, and cast out many demons, and while casting them out wasn’t letting the demons say anything, because they knew who he was.%vn~
          %u@3%u@5Early in the morning, before daybreak, he left and went out to a place where nobody was around and prayed and prayed there. %u@3%u@6Simon and those with him went out to hunt him down. %u@3%u@7They found him and, engaging him in conversation, said, “Everyone’s looking for you.” %u@3%u@8Continuing the conversation, he said, %r@“%R@L%r@e%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@l%r@s%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@w%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@v%r@i%r@c%r@i%r@n%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@.%r@” %u@3%u@9They went throughout all of Galilee preaching in the synagogues there and casting out demons.%vn~
          %u@4%u@0A leper approached him, pleading with him, “If you so desire, you can purge this disease from me.” %u@4%u@1He had pity on him, extended his hand, touched him, and pronounces, %r@“%R@I%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@s%r@i%r@r%r@e%r@;%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@r%r@g%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@s%r@e%r@a%r@s%r@e%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@4%u@2Immediately it left him; he was purged of the disease. %u@4%u@3Without wasting any time, he sternly and with an inner indignation gave him specific instructions and then cut him loose, %u@4%u@4telling him, %r@“%R@M%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@l%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@f%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@O%r@l%r@d%r@ %R@T%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@m%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@i%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@b%r@m%r@i%r@s%r@s%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@e%r@r%r@t%r@i%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@s%r@e%r@a%r@s%r@e%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@4%u@5But he departed and began going around enthusiastically telling lots of people what had happened and spreading the story and its acclamation around, resulting in him no longer being able to enter a city, but instead having to stay outside in the countryside.%vn~
      And they began to come to him from every direction.%vn~
%sb~
Mark Chapter 2%hb~
          %u@1Several days after entering Capernaum, word got out that he was staying in a house there. %u@2Many converged on it, to the extent that nobody could get in or out of the door anymore, and he kept on speaking the word of God to them. %u@3Four men arrived carrying a stretcher that had someone who was paralyzed on it. %u@4Not being able to carry him through the crowd, they pulled away the roof where he was and dug out a hole in order to lower the stretcher on which the paralyzed fellow was lying. %u@5Seeing their faith, Jesus said to the one paralyzed, %r@“%R@S%r@o%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@6Some of the designated teachers were sitting there mulling this over in their hearts, %u@7”How can he talk that way to this guy? He’s blaspheming; who’s able to forgive sins, except for the one-and-only God?” %u@8Immediately coming to the realization in his spirit exactly what they had thought up, Jesus engages them in conversation, %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@s%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@l%r@v%r@e%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@k%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@9%R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@s%r@i%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@r%r@a%r@l%r@y%r@z%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@,%r@’%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@G%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@r%r@e%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@l%r@k%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@’%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@0%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@o%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@…%r@”%r@ he turns and speaks to the paralyzed fellow, %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@”%r@…%R@I%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %r@p%r@i%r@c%r@k%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@r%r@e%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@1%u@2And in front of everybody he got up, without delay picked up his stretcher, and left, to everyone’s amazement and to their glorification of God saying, “We’ve never seen anything like this before.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@3Again, he ventured out near the sea. Everyone in the crowd started coming to him, and he began teaching them. %u@1%u@4As he was passing through, he saw Levi son of Alphaeus sitting at the customs table, and tells him directly, “Be my follower.” And he got up and became his follower. %u@1%u@5As he sat down to dine at home, many tax collectors and other sinners gathered there to eat with Jesus. %u@1%u@6The designated teachers, the ones affiliated with the Pharisees, observing that he takes meals with sinners and tax collectors, were saying to his disciples, “How is it that he dines with the tax collectors and other sinners?” %u@1%u@7Jesus heard this and said to them, %r@“%R@H%r@e%r@a%r@l%r@t%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@o%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@c%r@t%r@o%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@.%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@r%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@n%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@8John’s disciples and the Pharisees were fasting, and they approached him with a question, “What’s the reason that John’s disciples fast and the Pharisees’ disciples fast, but your disciples don’t fast?” %u@1%u@9Jesus said, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@r%r@o%r@n%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@?%r@ %R@A%r@s%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@0%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@.%r@”%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%R@N%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@u%r@s%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@d%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@a%r@r%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@;%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@w%r@i%r@s%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@s%r@e%r@l%r@f%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@l%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@a%r@p%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@p%r@p%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@e%r@s%r@h%r@l%r@y%r@-%r@s%r@q%r@u%r@e%r@e%r@z%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@a%r@p%r@e%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@;%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@w%r@i%r@s%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@r%r@s%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@u%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@ %R@R%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@a%r@p%r@e%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@2%u@3He happened to be passing through the grain fields on days which were Sabbath days, and his disciples began to make their way through the fields stripping the grain off the heads of the stalks. %u@2%u@4The Pharisees proceeded to say to him, “Take a look—they’re doing what’s forbidden on the Sabbath.” %u@2%u@5Looking deeper at the situation, he said to them, %r@“%R@D%r@i%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@D%r@a%r@v%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@u%r@n%r@g%r@r%r@y%r@—%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@H%r@o%r@w%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %R@A%r@b%r@i%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@a%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@c%r@e%r@p%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@—%r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@—%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@?%r@” %u@2%u@7He summarized, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@b%r@b%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@n%r@e%r@f%r@i%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@n%r@e%r@f%r@i%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@b%r@b%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@,%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@s%r@u%r@l%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@s%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@b%r@b%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@.%r@”%vn~
%sb~
Mark Chapter 3%hb~
          %u@1Yet again he introduced himself to those in the synagogue and attended a meeting. There was a man there with a shriveled-up hand, %u@2and they were watching him closely, to see if he was going to heal him on the Sabbath, so that they’d have something to accuse him of. %u@3He addressed the man with the shriveled-up hand, %r@“%R@G%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@” %u@4He challenged them, %r@“%R@I%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@m%r@i%r@s%r@s%r@i%r@b%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@b%r@b%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@f%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@?%r@”%r@ They remained silent. %u@5He looked all around, staring at them in fury, being deeply grieved over the callousness of their hearts, and said to the man intently, %r@“%R@S%r@t%r@r%r@e%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@.%r@”%r@ He stretched it out, and his hand was restored. %u@6After the Pharisees departed, they wasted no time in meeting with the Herodians about him, to figure out how they could kill him.%vn~
          %u@7Jesus, accompanied by his disciples, ventured over to the sea, and a great many followed him from Galilee, and from Judea, %u@8and from Jerusalem, and from Idumea, and from the other side of the Jordan River, and from the areas around Tyre and Sidon—a great many, hearing about how much he was doing, went to him. %u@9And because of the crowd, he spoke to his disciples about getting a boat, so that they wouldn’t press in on him. %u@1%u@0Indeed, he treated many, resulting in them mobbing him in order that they might receive a touch from him, whoever was getting the tar beaten out of him by disease or whatnot. %u@1%u@1And, time and time again, the demonic spirits, when they saw him, prostrated themselves before him in homage and screamed out, “You are the Son of God!” %u@1%u@2And, time and time again, he was sternly silencing them so they would not cause him to be plainly known as such.%vn~
          %u@1%u@3He hiked up a mountain and summoned those whom he had been wanting to have as his disciples, and they came to him. %u@1%u@4He made twelve, and he made them so that they would be with him and so that he could send them out to preach his message %u@1%u@5and to have authority to cast out demons. %u@1%u@6He assigned the name “Peter” to Simon, %u@1%u@7and there was James son of Zebedee and his brother John, to whom he assigned the name “Sons of Thunder,” %u@1%u@8Andrew, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James son of Alphaeus, Thaddeus, Simon the Canaaanite (i.e., Zealot), %u@1%u@9and Judas Iscariot, his betrayer.%vn~
          %u@2%u@0Now he came to a house. Once again, the crowd converged on it, resulting in them not being able to get a bite to eat. %u@2%u@1When the neighbors caught wind of this, they came out to get him under control, since they had been saying all along that he’s lost his mind. %u@2%u@2And the designated teachers, the Scribes, made the journey from Jerusalem and had been saying that he’s possessed by the Chief Demon himself, and that, by means of the chief, he casts out the underling-demons. %u@2%u@3He called them over and began to teach them by using analogies: %r@“%R@H%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%R@I%r@f%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@v%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@i%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@g%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@p%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@g%r@a%r@n%r@i%r@z%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@v%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@i%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@g%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@g%r@a%r@n%r@i%r@z%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@p%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@p%r@p%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@l%r@i%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@s%r@t%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@c%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@p%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@—%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@M%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@t%r@—%r@n%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@ %r@g%r@u%r@y%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@r%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@b%r@d%r@u%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@ %r@g%r@u%r@y%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@I%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@r%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@n%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@l%r@k%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@b%r@l%r@a%r@s%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@l%r@u%r@r%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@9%r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@l%r@a%r@s%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@H%r@o%r@l%r@y%r@ %R@S%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@—%r@h%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@g%r@u%r@i%r@l%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@ %r@e%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@n%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@.%r@” %u@3%u@0He said all this because they were going about saying, “He has a demonic spirit.”%vn~
          %u@3%u@1His mother and brothers came and were standing outside and sent him word, calling on him. %u@3%u@2Seated around him was a crowd, and they said to him, “Hey, your mother and your brothers are outside looking for you.” %u@3%u@3Surprisingly, he replied, %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@?%r@” %u@3%u@4He looked around at those sitting in a circle around him and said, %r@“%R@T%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@—%r@m%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@.%r@”%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@W%r@h%r@o%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@”%vn~
%sb~
Mark Chapter 4%hb~
          %u@1On another occasion, he began to teach near the sea. A huge crowd gathered around him, causing him to have to get in a boat and sit out in the sea; everyone in the crowd stayed on dry land and squeezed in as close as they could to the shoreline. %u@2He began to teach them by means of analogy, telling many. In one of his sermons he was telling them this: %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@”%R@L%r@i%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@!%r@ %R@T%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@r%r@m%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@w%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%R@W%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@w%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@p%r@p%r@e%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@w%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@i%r@r%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@,%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%r@w%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@o%r@c%r@k%r@y%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@u%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@i%r@l%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@i%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@m%r@m%r@e%r@d%r@i%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@r%r@m%r@i%r@n%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@n%r@ %r@r%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@c%r@o%r@r%r@c%r@h%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@d%r@u%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@e%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@b%r@l%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@ %r@r%r@o%r@o%r@t%r@s%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@Y%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@f%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@r%r@u%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@,%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@g%r@u%r@l%r@f%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@h%r@o%r@k%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@i%r@e%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@d%r@u%r@c%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@N%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@w%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@i%r@e%r@l%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@d%r@u%r@c%r@e%r@:%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@i%r@e%r@l%r@d%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@3%r@0%r@-%r@t%r@o%r@-%r@1%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@6%r@0%r@-%r@t%r@o%r@-%r@1%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@1%r@0%r@0%r@-%r@t%r@o%r@-%r@1%r@.%r@” %u@9And he kept telling them, %r@“%R@A%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@f%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@i%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@0When they got together by themselves, those around him, along with the Twelve, asked him about the analogies. %u@1%u@1He began by saying, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@’%r@s%r@ %R@I%r@n%r@v%r@o%r@l%r@v%r@e%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@(%R@G%r@o%r@d%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@)%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@s%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@ %r@(%r@i%r@.%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@)%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@a%r@l%r@o%r@g%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@s%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@,%r@%vn~
%r@%si~
%r@“%R@W%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@%vp~
%r@(%r@i%r@.%r@e%r@.%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@)%r@,%r@%vp~
%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@p%r@r%r@e%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@d%r@%vp~
%r@(%r@i%r@.%r@e%r@.%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@x%r@t%r@)%r@,%r@%vp~
%R@L%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@u%r@r%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@”%r@%vp~
%si~
          %u@1%u@3He said, %r@“%R@D%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@a%r@l%r@o%r@g%r@y%r@?%r@ %R@H%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@           %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%R@H%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@c%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@m%r@p%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@s%r@k%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@u%r@c%r@h%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@?%r@ %R@I%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@m%r@p%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%R@I%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@d%r@d%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@i%r@f%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@s%r@e%r@l%r@f%r@,%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@r%r@p%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@d%r@d%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@i%r@f%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%R@A%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@f%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@i%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%R@H%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@c%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@“%R@M%r@o%r@n%r@i%r@t%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@.%r@ %R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@q%r@u%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@f%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@i%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@q%r@u%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@e%r@m%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@f%r@f%r@i%r@c%r@i%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@F%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@;%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@H%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@c%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@
