%r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@p%r@t%r@i%r@z%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@k%r@e%r@p%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@r%r@u%r@c%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@f%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@m%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@p%r@e%r@r%r@n%r@a%r@t%r@u%r@r%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@g%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@c%r@c%r@o%r@m%r@p%r@a%r@n%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@d%r@:%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@o%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@s%r@;%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@e%r@a%r@k%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@u%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@,%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@-%r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@d%r@-%r@b%r@e%r@f%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@n%r@g%r@u%r@a%r@g%r@e%r@s%r@;%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@m%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@r%r@p%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@;%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@k%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@p%r@o%r@i%r@s%r@o%r@n%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@e%r@r%r@t%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@r%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@;%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@c%r@k%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@c%r@k%r@l%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@9So then the Lord Jesus, after speaking to them, was taken up into the sky and assumed his position as God’s chief executive. %u@2%u@0But those very disciples went out and preached everywhere, the Lord working alongside and cooperating with them like a fellow-worker, and the message kept on being confirmed, established, and made certain by means of the supernatural signs following happening right there on the spot, right on their heels.%vn~

The Gospel of Luke%ha~
       Luke, the beloved physician (Col . 4:14), the faithful companion of Paul, is the author of one of the four officially-sponsored Gospels. We assume that Paul authorized Luke to write it, and since it was associated with Paul, it’s target audience was the gentile church, more specifically the Christians planted by Paul’s ministry. Evidence points to Luke being a slave or a freedman, serving or having served one Theophilus, for whose benefit he writes not only the Gospel of Luke but its sequel, the Book of Acts.%nv~
       The facts Luke recorded in his Gospel were obtained from him conducting first-hand interviews (he says this in 1:2) with many eyewitnesses to the ministry of Jesus. To do this, Luke would have had to have spent a few months in Israel, and would have spoken directly with Mary the mother of Jesus and recorded her very words in order to obtain such precise details of Jesus’s birth. The likely time of his doing these interviews would have been around AD 55, when Paul was in Israel during his third missionary journey. Had it been any later than this, these eyewitnesses would have been deceased already, not to speak of the sack of Jerusalem in AD 70.%nv~
       Luke was thorough and meticulous. He was likely a native Greek speaker; his command of Greek surpasses Matthew’s, Mark’s, and John’s by a large measure, and is only rivaled by Paul’s and by those who wrote the epistles of Jude and Hebrews. Luke has full command of the nuanced richness of the Greek language, and he can capture in a word or a word inflection something which takes an entire phrase to render in English.%nv~
       Though Luke has the education and intelligence to write complex, sophisticated passages—which he does in Luke 1:1–4—he refrains from doing so and writes in a down-to-earth manner throughout his book. From time to time, he dresses up a sentence or two, using colorful wording where more straightforward wording would suffice. An example is Luke 7:1; another example is Luke 8:15 “beautiful and morally good;” another example is the simile of Luke 22:44, where Luke compares Jesus sweat to drops of blood. But throughout the book, he is mindful of detail and correctness, as what he writes must reflect what the eyewitnesses told him in face-to-face interviews. In the example of the Pharisee and the tax collector praying at the temple (Luke 18:11,13), Luke says that both stood, but uses a different form of the same verb to stand, subtlety conveying the difference in their standing postures. Moreover in 18:13, Luke’s prose garnishes the story beautifully (literal rendering): “But the tax collector standing at a distance was not wanting neither to lift up the eyes to heaven.” Luke is sparing in his use of special forms and expressions, but by being sparing when he does use special forms, his usage is more effective. For example, in Luke 17:37, Luke uses the present tense to mean the past tense—he does not do that often, like in the other Gospels.%nv~
       Of the four Gospels, Luke captures the most sober and chilling warnings of the judgment to come: do the right thing or pay for it later, even if the payment might be deferred to the life to come. Some examples of this are as follows. Luke 12:20: “Fool—the Grim Reaper is coming for you this very night. Now everything you saved away: who’s it going to go to?” Luke 13:8,9: “The gardener considered things and replied, ‘Boss, leave it be this year as well; meanwhile, I’ll dig around it and put down fertilizer, and we’ll see if it produces figs in the coming year. But if it doesn’t, you can cut it down.” Luke 13:27,28: “Get away from me, the lot of you, practitioners of wrong-doing.’ There will be the weeping and the gnashing of teeth, at that time when Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and all the prophets connected with God’s involvement with mankind (God’s kingdom) will be seen. Those people, though, get the boot.” Luke 14:24: “I’ll tell you this much: not a single one of those people who were invited will taste even a morsel of my dinner.” The rich man and Lazarus (Luke 16). Luke 19:27: “However, my enemies, those who didn’t want me to rule over them as their king, bring them here and slay them right in front of me.”%nv~
%sb~
Luke Chapter 1%hb~
          %u@1In light of the fact that many have attempted to compose a narrative concerning the deeds which have been carried out to fulfillment among us, %u@2and to record it in the same way that they—those from the get-go who became eye-witnesses and custodians of the entire affair—delivered and entrusted it to us, %u@3it seemed like a good idea for me to follow up after them and write something for you, something that starts from the very beginning and which is completely accurate and in sequential order, Lord Theophilus, %u@4so that you would become thoroughly acquainted with the affairs which you’ve learned by word of mouth, and that you would know them with certainty.%vn~
          %u@5It came to pass in the days of Herod, king of the Jews, that there was a certain priest named Zechariah, from the Order of Abijah, and he had a wife who was of the priestly caste—and her name was Elizabeth. %u@6Both of them were righteous in the sight of God, their conduct, from God’s perspective, was that they complied with all the commandments and expectations of correct behavior. %u@7They had no children, because Elizabeth couldn’t have any children, and both were now elderly.%vn~
          %u@8Now during his priestly order’s timeslot in the rotation schedule, he happened to be the one performing the priestly duties in the holy presence of God %u@9(the appointment being determined according to the priests’ tradition of rolling dice), having entered into the temple sanctuary itself to light the incense; %u@1%u@0and everyone who was in the multitude, a multitude of the folk-people, was outside praying during the hour of the incense lighting ritual. %u@1%u@1So now, an angel sent from the Lord appeared to him standing to the right of the Altar of Incense. %u@1%u@2Looking at the angel, Zechariah became disturbed, and fear fell upon him. %u@1%u@3The angel said to him, “Don’t be afraid, Zechariah; you see, your prayer has been taken to heart, and your wife Elizabeth shall bear you a son, and you’ll name him John. %u@1%u@4He’ll be a cause of joy and exultation for you, and many will rejoice at his birth. %u@1%u@5Indeed, he’ll be used mightily by the Lord and won’t drink wine or liquor—absolutely won’t—and he’ll be filled with the Holy Spirit while still in his mother’s womb, %u@1%u@6and many native Israelites will heed the Lord their God. %u@1%u@7The Lord will use him as a herald in a spirit and power the likeness of which Elijah had, to soften the hearts of the fathers towards the children, and the skeptics and the disobedient to the sensibility of the ways of the righteous, to bring about a fully-refined people for the Lord.” %u@1%u@8Zechariah said to the angel, “Just how will the realization of these things come to me? The fact is, I’m old, and my wife is well-past her prime.” %u@1%u@9The angel replied, “I am the high-ranking angel Gabriel: the one who stands in the presence of God. Concerning these things, He sent me to speak to you and deliver the good news. %u@2%u@0See here now—you will remain silent, unable to speak, until the time comes that these things come to pass, as a consequence of you not having believed my words, which will be fulfilled in the course of good time.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@1The people were expecting Zechariah to have come out already and were baffled at how long a time he was spending in the temple. %u@2%u@2When he came out, he was unable to speak to them, and they realized that he’d seen a vision while inside the temple. He was gesturing to them, all the while remaining mute. %u@2%u@3When his order’s timeslot for priestly service was up, he left to go back home. %u@2%u@4Some time afterwards, his wife Elizabeth conceived, and during the five months that she was keeping herself in seclusion, she kept on saying, %u@2%u@5”All this because the Lord wanted things to turn out for me in a way that would remove my shame in the eyes of others.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@6Now in the sixth month of Elizabeth’s pregnancy, God sent the angel Gabriel to a city in Galilee called Nazareth, %u@2%u@7to a young, never-married woman engaged to a man named Joseph, who was a direct descendant of David—and the name of this young woman was Mary. %u@2%u@8He entered the physical world right in front of her and said, %vn~
      “Greetings, favored-one, the Lord be with you.” %u@2%u@9Now she was deeply disturbed at the remark and was trying to figure out what the nature of the visit would be. %u@3%u@0The angel said to her, “Don’t be afraid, Mary; the fact is, you’ve found favor with God. %u@3%u@1See here now—you’ll conceive and give birth to a son, and you’ll name him ‘Jesus.’ %u@3%u@2He’ll be capable, noteworthy, and accomplished and will be called a son of the Most High. The Lord God will give him the throne of his ancestor David, %u@3%u@3and he’ll reign forever over the Israeli people, and his kingdom will never come to an end.” %vn~
          %u@3%u@4Mary said to the angel, “How will this come about, since I don’t have a husband with whom to be intimate?”%vn~
       %u@3%u@5The angel answered, “The Holy Spirit will come over you, and the miraculous power of the Most High will engulf you. For this reason, the one you’re giving birth to is holy, and he’ll be called a son of God. %u@3%u@6Take a look—in her old age, your relative Elizabeth—even she—is pregnant with a son; the one everyone took for granted was infertile—this is her sixth month of pregnancy. %u@3%u@7You see, with God, all things are possible.”%vn~
          %u@3%u@8Mary said, “I present myself as the servant of the Lord. Let things come to pass with regard to me according to your word.” And the angel departed from her.%vn~
          %u@3%u@9During this time, Mary took a trip into the hill country, to a town in Judea. %u@4%u@0She entered Zechariah’s house and was welcomed enthusiastically by Elizabeth. %u@4%u@1It so happened that when Elizabeth heard Mary’s greeting, the baby leaped in her womb; Elizabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit, %u@4%u@2and with a great cry uttered back, “You in particular among women be blessed, (that is, the recipient of good things); and blessed be, (that is, let the pronouncement of goodness be over), the produce of your womb. %u@4%u@3How did I get such an honor, that the mother of my Lord would come to visit me? %u@4%u@4In fact—get this—the moment the sound of your greeting entered my ear, the baby I’m carrying leaped in exultation. %u@4%u@5She who believed is blessed, because it will be a realization of those things which have been spoken to her and established from the Lord.”%vn~
          %u@4%u@6And Mary said,%vn~
%sp~
%u@4%u@7”My life-being extols the Lord%vp~
And my spirit has heaped exultation upon God my Savior%vp~
%u@4%u@8Because He took interest in the abasement of his slave.%vp~
Yes indeed—and—hey—from now on%vp~
All generations will call me blessed%vp~
%u@4%u@9Because he has done great things for me, the Capable One,%vp~
And holy is His name,%vp~
%u@5%u@0And His mercy is directed towards those%vp~
Who have a deep reverence for Him.%vp~
For generation upon generation%vp~
%u@5%u@1The One exuding power intervened%vp~
In the affairs of man and did this:%vp~
He routed those who are high-and-mighty%vp~
Where the intention of their heart is concerned.%vp~
%u@5%u@2He pulled down rulers from their thrones%vp~
And exalted the abased.%vp~
%u@5%u@3From out of good things He filled the hungry up,%vp~
And He punted the rich,%vp~
Sending them away empty-handed.%vp~
%u@5%u@4He took the responsibility of caring for Israel, his child,%vp~
To take heed and remember mercy,%vp~
%u@5%u@5In accordance to what he said to our ancestors,%vp~
To Abraham and to his descendants until the end of time.”%vp~
%sp~
          %u@5%u@6Mary remained with her for three months and set out for the return trip back home. %u@5%u@7Now Elizabeth’s due-date arrived, and she gave birth to a son. %u@5%u@8Her neighbors and relatives heard that the Lord showered tremendous mercy on her and rejoiced with her joy and congratulated her. %u@5%u@9When the eighth day after birth came, they went to circumcise the child, and they were thinking of naming him after his father Zechariah. %u@6%u@0His mother spoke up and said,%vn~
      “No—he’ll be named John instead.”%vn~
          %u@6%u@1They told her, “You don’t have any relatives who go by that name.”%vn~
          %u@6%u@2They started gesturing to his father what he might possibly want to name him. %u@6%u@3He asked for a chalkboard and wrote, “His name will be John.”%vn~
      Everyone was taken back: %u@6%u@4he immediately regained his ability to talk, and he began speaking, uttering praises to God. %u@6%u@5A deep reverence came over all his neighbors, and the whole hill country of Judea kept on talking about all these matters; %u@6%u@6the reports settled deep in the heart of everyone who heard them: they were saying, “What will come of this child as a result?” The fact is, God was directing the course of his life.%vn~
          %u@6%u@7Zechariah, his father, was filled with the Holy Spirit and prophesied,%vn~
%si~
%u@6%u@8Blessed is the Lord God of Israel,%vp~
Because He showed up and did a spiritual service for His people%vp~
%u@6%u@9And got a horn ready, a horn%vp~
Which signals security and the end to our misery,%vp~
Ready to blow, to be a cue for us%vp~
By means of the lineage of David, His son%vp~
%u@7%u@0In accordance to what He spoke%vp~
Through the mouth of the holy people who lived long ago%vp~
Prophesying about him from the beginning of time:%vp~
%si~
%u@7%u@1”Security and the end to our misery from our enemies%vp~
And from the ability of those who hate us to do us harm:%vp~
%u@7%u@2To perform an act of mercy in the company of our ancestors%vp~
And to remember His holy covenant,%vp~
%u@7%u@3An oath which He swore to our ancestor Abraham:%vp~
%u@7%u@4The promise to grant us bold raid-and-rescue operations%vp~
To get us out from the clutches of our enemies;%vp~
To be continuously holding worship services dedicated to Him%vp~
%u@7%u@5In piety, holiness, and correctness%vp~
In His midst for all the days of our lives.”%vp~
%si~
%u@7%u@6Now you, child, will be called a prophet of the Most High%vp~
You see, you’re destined to be a trailblazer for the Lord%vp~
To prepare the road that he’ll take%vp~
%u@7%u@7To impart to his people%vp~
The comprehension of their security and of an end to their misery%vp~
By means of the forgiveness of their sins%vp~
%u@7%u@8Through deep, heartfelt mercies from our God,%vp~
By which mercies a sunrise to noon-like epoch will come visit us,%vp~
%u@7%u@9To shine upon those in darkness,%vp~
Upon those sitting under a death-shadow,%vp~
To put us on the path to peace.%vp~
%si~
          %u@8%u@0The child grew and grew and became stronger and stronger in spirit, and he stayed out in the wilderness until the time came for his public appearance to the nation of Israel.%vn~
%sb~
Luke Chapter 2%hb~
          %u@1Around that time, an edict from Caesar Augustus was issued to the entire civilized world.%u@ %u@2This edict was a census, and this census was the first one issued during the tenure of Quirinius, the ruler of the Roman province of Syria. %u@3Everyone was either coming or going to be registered, each to the city he belonged to. %u@4So Joseph went from the city of Nazareth in Galilee to Judea, to the city of David, which is called “Bethlehem,” on account of him being of the lineage of and being a descendant of David, %u@5to be registered for the census along with his fiancée Mary, who was expecting. %u@6While they were there, her due-date arrived, %u@7and she gave birth to a son, her firstborn, wrapped him in a blanket, and laid him in a manger, since there wasn’t any room for them in the upstairs floor of the house they were at.%vn~
          %u@8Nearby in the same area, there were shepherds working the night shift outdoors, keeping an eye on their sheep. %u@9An angel sent from the Lord appeared to them, and the glory of the Lord shined all around them, and they became very frightened. %u@1%u@0The angel said to them, “Don’t be afraid, since I’m here, you see, to announce to you something good, a message about the tremendous grace which will be given to all the people, %u@1%u@1since this day a savior, who is Christ the Lord, was born in your midst in the city of David. %u@1%u@2This is the way you’ll spot him: you’ll find a baby all wrapped up lying in a manger.” %u@1%u@3And suddenly a multitude of troops from the angels in heaven appeared together with the angel praising God, saying over and over,%vn~
%si~
%u@1%u@4Glory to God to the max,%vp~
And peace be upon the Earth among men of good intent%vp~
%si~
          %u@1%u@5When the angels departed from them back to heaven, the shepherds began saying to one another, “Let’s go from one end of Bethlehem to the other, right this moment, until we get to look into this situation, this thing that the Lord informed us of.” %u@1%u@6They left in a hurry and discovered it: Mary, Joseph, and the baby lying in the manger. %u@1%u@7While looking things over, they made known the details of the message spoken to them in regard to this very child. %u@1%u@8Many of those who had heard what was said were amazed at what the shepherds were telling them; %u@1%u@9Mary latched on to all these words while they were being deposited into her heart and collected there. %u@2%u@0The shepherds returned glorifying and praising God for everything they heard about and saw, which was in fact just like it had been spoken to them.%vn~
          %u@2%u@1When the eighth day, the day for him to be circumcised, rolled around, they named him “Jesus,” the name given by the angel before he was conceived. %u@2%u@2And when the purification time, the span of time in accordance with the Old Testament statute, had expired, they took him over to Jerusalem to be presented to the Lord, %u@2%u@3just as it’s written in the Old Testament, “Every man-child who is a mother’s first delivery shall be designated as set aside for the Lord,” %u@2%u@4and to offer up a sacrifice according to the commandment in the Old Testament, “a pair of turtledoves or two young doves.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@5Now, you see, there was a man in Jerusalem named Simeon, and this fellow was righteous and devout, awaiting Israel’s consolation, and the Holy Spirit was upon him. %u@2%u@6He had been informed in a consultation by the Holy Spirit that he won’t encounter death before seeing Christ the Lord. %u@2%u@7By the Spirit, he went to the temple and to the parents as they were presenting the child Jesus, carrying out the Old Testament ritual concerning him, %u@2%u@8and he himself took him into his arms, gave a blessing to God, and said,%vn~
%si~
%u@2%u@9”At this time You’re releasing Your servant%vp~
From his service in peace, Master,%vp~
Just like You said you would,%vp~
%u@3%u@0Because my eyes have seen Your rescue program,%vp~
%u@3%u@1That which You’ve prepared in accordance with%vp~
The disposition of the people:%vp~
%u@3%u@2A light resulting in a revelation for the nations%vp~
And resulting in your people Israel’s high regard.”%vp~
%si~
          %u@3%u@3His father and mother were surprised by what was spoken about him. %u@3%u@4Simeon pronounced a blessing on them and said to Mary, “You see, this fellow is destined to be the cause of the downfall and rejuvenation of many in Israel and to be a portent spoken against them. %u@3%u@5And for you—your very life-being will be gone through with a sword, pierced from end to end, so that from out of many hearts, contemplations and reasonings would be revealed.”%vn~
          %u@3%u@6There was a prophetess named Anna, daughter of Phanuel, of the tribe of Asher. She was up there in years, having married as a young woman, her marriage lasting for seven years, %u@3%u@7and after that being a widow for 84 years, during which time she hadn’t been absent from the temple, fasting and praying day and night in service to God. %u@3%u@8At the same time the ritual was going on, she went over and stood by their side, all the while professing affirmations in acknowledgement to God and speaking about Him to all those in Jerusalem awaiting the rectification of their dire straits.%vn~
          %u@3%u@9When all the rituals prescribed by the Old Testament were concluded, they left for Galilee, to their hometown of Nazareth. %u@4%u@0Now the child kept on growing and kept on getting stronger, while being filled with wisdom, and God’s favor was upon him.%vn~
          %u@4%u@1Year after year, his parents kept going back to Jerusalem, to the Passover festival, %u@4%u@2and when he was twelve years old, they went to Jerusalem according to festival custom. %u@4%u@3When the festival, which lasted a few days, was over, as they were departing, the child Jesus remained in Jerusalem, but his parents were unaware. %u@4%u@4Having assumed that he was somewhere in the caravan, they were on the road a few days and began searching for him among their relatives and acquaintances, %u@4%u@5but they weren’t able to find him. They returned to Jerusalem in search of him.%vn~
          %u@4%u@6It so happened that after three days they found him in the temple sitting in the middle of the teachers, listening to them and asking them questions. %u@4%u@7All of those who were listening to him were amazed at his understanding—his ability to put things together—and at his answers. %u@4%u@8Upon seeing this, his parents were taken aback, and his mother said to him, “Child, why have you treated us this way? Look—your father and I have been pulling our hair out looking for you.” %u@4%u@9He said to them, “Just why now were you searching for me? Didn’t you know that I had to be in the midst of my Father’s interests?” %u@5%u@0They didn’t put all the pieces together from the remark that was spoken to them. %u@5%u@1He left with them and went to Nazareth, and he was staying in submission to their authority. His mother in her heart latched on to all these incidences, one after another; %u@5%u@2and Jesus continued forging ahead in wisdom, stature, and in God’s and in peoples’ favor.%vn~
%sb~
Luke Chapter 3%hb~
          %u@1In the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar, while Pontius Pilate was governor of Judea, and Herod the ruler in Galilee (his brother Philip, though, was the ruler of the regions Iturea and Traconitis, and Lysanias the ruler of Abiline), %u@2during the tenure of the high priests Annas and Caiaphas, the word of the Lord (i.e. a prophetic message) came to John son of Zechariah while in the countryside. %u@3He went into all the surrounding regions of the Jordan preaching a baptism—a water immersion-type of initiation ceremony—signifying a total commitment to a change in conduct to live the right way and initiating into a forgiveness of sins., %u@4as it’s been written in the Book of Isaiah, the prophet:%vn~
%sp~
The sound of shouting in the countryside:%vp~
“Block off the road the Lord will take!%vp~
Barricade the streets he’ll be on!” %vp~
%u@5All valleys will be filled in%vp~
And all hills will be leveled;%vp~
All the windy roads will get straightened out%vp~
And all the rough roads will be resurfaced;%vp~
%u@6Every living being will witness God’s rescue program.”%vp~
%si~
          %u@7Accordingly, he went on and on saying to the crowd coming out to be baptized by him, “You offspring of vipers, who convinced you to run for your lives because of the coming wrath? %u@8In line with this, produce the corresponding actions on par with a change for the better—and don’t start in with this talk, saying among yourselves, ‘We’re in with God because we’re descendants of Abraham.’ Let me tell you what—the fact is, God can create from scratch and establish descendants for Abraham from out of these stones. %u@9The axe is already lying next to the tree trunk ready to be used to cut the tree down; in line with this, all trees not producing good fruit will be hacked out and cast into a fire.” %u@1%u@0The crowd thereupon asked him,%vn~
      “How then are we supposed to conduct our lives?”%vn~
          %u@1%u@1He replied to them by saying, “Whoever has two shirts, give one to him who doesn’t have any, and the one who has food do the same.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@2Tax collectors also came to be baptized and said, “Teacher, how are we supposed to conduct our lives?”%vn~
          %u@1%u@3He said, “Don’t take anything more than what the quotas and tax rates mandate.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@4Soldiers also were questioning him, “How are we too supposed to act?”, and he said to them,%vn~
      “Don’t shake people down for money or take bribes from racketeers, and be content with your wages.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@5While the people were in a state of anticipation, everybody was thinking the circumstances concerning John over in their heart, going back and forth, trying to decide whether he was the Messiah—the Christ—or not. %u@1%u@6John declared to them all, “Me—I baptize in water. But one’s coming who’s greater than me, one whom I’m not worthy enough to carry around by the soles of his shoes. He, for his part, will baptize you in a fiery manifestation of the Holy Spirit. %u@1%u@7One who, with the winnowing fork in his hand, will clear everything off his threshing floor and will gather the wheat into his silo, but will burn up the chaff with a fire that will never be put out.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@8So then, at many times and in many different ways exhorting, instructing, appealing to, and pleading with the people, again and again he made the good news known. %u@1%u@9But now, for the ruler Herod, being called out by him in regard to his brother’s wife Herodias and in regard to all the wickedness that he, Herod, did, %u@2%u@0this was the last straw, and he locked him up in jail.%vn~
          %u@2%u@1In the course of baptizing all the people, including Jesus, while he was being baptized and was praying, the sky opened up, %u@2%u@2the Holy Spirit came down in bodily form upon him, appearing like a dove, and out of the sky a voice said, “You are my Beloved Son, with whom I’m pleased.%vn~
          %u@2%u@3Now Jesus himself was around thirty years old, considered to be the son of Joseph, who’s the son of Heli, %u@2%u@4the son of Matthat, of Levi, of Melki, of Jannai, of Joseph, %u@2%u@5of Mattathias, of Amos, of Nahum, of Esli, of Naggai, %u@2%u@6of Maath, of Mattathias, of Semein, of Josek, of Joda, %u@2%u@7of Joanan, of Rhesa, of Zerubbabel, of Shelatiel, of Neri, %u@2%u@8of Melki, of Addi, of Cosam, of Elmadam, of Er, %u@2%u@9of Joshua, or Eliezer, of Jorim, of Matthat, of Levi, %u@3%u@0of Simeon, of Judah, of Joseph, of Jonam, of Eliakim, %u@3%u@1of Melea, of Menna, of Mattatha, of Nathan, of David, %u@3%u@2of Jesse, of Obed, of Boaz, of Salmon, of Nahshon, %u@3%u@3of Amminadab, of Ram, of Hezron, of Perez, of Judah, %u@3%u@4of Jacob, of Isaac, of Abraham, of Terah, of Nahor, %u@3%u@5of Serug, of Reu, of Peleg, of Eber, of Shelah, %u@3%u@6of Cainan, of Arphaxad, of Shem, of Noah, of Lamech, %u@3%u@7of Methuselah, of Enoch, of Jared, of Mahalalel, of Kenan, %u@3%u@8of Enosh, of Seth, of Adam, of God.%vn~
%sb~
Luke Chapter 4%hb~
          %u@1Now Jesus, full of the Holy Spirit, withdrew from the Jordan region and proceeded to be led by the Spirit in the wilderness, %u@2while for forty days the devil kept trying to break him using trials and temptations. He wasn’t eating anything during those days, and as that season of time was drawing to its conclusion, he was famished. %u@3So the devil said to him, “If you enjoy the status of Son of God, speak to this rock here so that it becomes bread.” %u@4Jesus answered back to him, %r@“%R@I%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@S%r@c%r@r%r@i%r@p%r@t%r@u%r@r%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@M%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@.%r@’%r@” %u@5He took him up and showed him in a brief moment all the kingdoms of the inhabited world, %u@6and the devil said to him, “I will give you the authority over all of these and all the wonderful things in them, since it was granted to me and to whomever I might desire to give it. %u@7So now, if you pay homage to me in obeisance, all of this will be yours.” %u@8Jesus’s reply to him was, %r@“%R@I%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@S%r@c%r@r%r@i%r@p%r@t%r@u%r@r%r@e%r@,%r@”%r@%vn~
%r@%si~
%r@“%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@m%r@a%r@g%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@L%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@%vp~
%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %R@H%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@i%r@t%r@u%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@s%r@h%r@i%r@p%r@”%r@%vp~
%si~
%u@9He led him to Jerusalem and stood him on top of the battlements of the temple roof and said to him, “If you enjoy the status of Son of God, jump down from here; %u@1%u@0you see, it’s been written in Scripture,”%nn~
%si~
“Concerning you, His angels are commanded%vp~
To keep a close eye on you and protect you%vp~
%si~
%u@1%u@1”…and, you see,”%nn~
%si~
“They’ll snatch you out of the way with their bare hands%vp~
To prevent your foot from impacting a stone”%vp~
%si~
%u@1%u@2And Jesus’s reply to him was, %r@“%R@I%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@L%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@ %R@H%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@m%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@i%r@l%r@s%r@.%r@’%r@”%r@ %u@1%u@3And the devil, having run through his list of temptations, departed from him for the time being.%nn~
          %u@1%u@4Jesus returned to Galilee in the miracle-working power of the Spirit. His renown spread throughout the surrounding area. %u@1%u@5He began to go about teaching in their synagogues, while being hailed and applauded by many.%vn~
          %u@1%u@6He went to Nazareth, where he was raised, and introduced himself to those in the synagogue and attended their meeting as he was in the habit of doing on days which were Sabbaths. He stood up and came forward to do a reading. %u@1%u@7A scroll was handed to him, the Book of Isaiah (the prophet), and he opened the book and found the place where it’s written,%vn~
%si~
%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@L%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@%vp~
%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %R@H%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@%vp~
%R@H%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@o%r@w%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@e%r@c%r@i%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@s%r@p%r@e%r@n%r@s%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@%vp~
%R@O%r@f%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@v%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@p%r@o%r@w%r@e%r@r%r@%vp~
%R@T%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@i%r@t%r@u%r@t%r@e%r@.%r@%vp~
%R@H%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@n%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@c%r@l%r@a%r@i%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@c%r@h%r@%vp~
%R@T%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@p%r@t%r@i%r@v%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@l%r@e%r@a%r@s%r@e%r@%vp~
%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@o%r@r%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@;%r@%vp~
%R@T%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@s%r@p%r@a%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@w%r@n%r@t%r@r%r@o%r@d%r@d%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@v%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@%vp~
%R@D%r@i%r@s%r@c%r@h%r@a%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@a%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@l%r@e%r@a%r@s%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@b%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@%vp~
%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@;%r@%vp~
%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@9%R@T%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@n%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@c%r@l%r@a%r@i%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@c%r@h%r@%vp~
%R@A%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@a%r@s%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@-%r@c%r@e%r@l%r@e%r@b%r@r%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@o%r@n%r@s%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@L%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@.%r@%vp~
%si~
%u@2%u@0Once he rolled the scroll back up, packed it way, and gave it to the attendant, he seated himself before them in order to deliver a message; everyone in the synagogue had their eyes fixed on him. %u@2%u@1He proceeded to speak, telling them that, this day, their own ears have witnessed the fulfillment of this very Scripture. %u@2%u@2Everyone was caught up in taking note of him and in being amazed at the eloquence of what flowed out of his mouth, and were saying, “Isn’t this guy Joseph’s son?”—or something to that effect. %u@2%u@3He said to them, %r@“%R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@P%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@—%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@p%r@p%r@e%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@C%r@a%r@p%r@e%r@r%r@n%r@a%r@u%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@f%r@o%r@l%r@k%r@.%r@’%r@”%r@ %u@2%u@4Then he said, %r@“%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@n%r@k%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@:%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@l%r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@f%r@o%r@l%r@k%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@o%r@t%r@-%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@r%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@—%r@b%r@a%r@c%r@k%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@y%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@E%r@l%r@i%r@j%r@a%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@d%r@o%r@w%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@I%r@s%r@r%r@a%r@e%r@l%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@k%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@l%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@f%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@r%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@a%r@c%r@t%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@r%r@e%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@l%r@f%r@ %r@y%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@h%r@u%r@g%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@m%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@p%r@p%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@E%r@l%r@i%r@j%r@a%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@c%r@e%r@p%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@m%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@Z%r@a%r@r%r@e%r@p%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@S%r@i%r@d%r@o%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@d%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@y%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@p%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@I%r@s%r@r%r@a%r@e%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@i%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@p%r@h%r@e%r@t%r@ %R@E%r@l%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@a%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@p%r@r%r@o%r@s%r@y%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@r%r@g%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@c%r@e%r@p%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@y%r@r%r@i%r@a%r@n%r@ %R@N%r@a%r@a%r@m%r@a%r@n%r@.%r@”%nn~
          %u@2%u@8Hearing this, everyone in the synagogue was filled with rage, %u@2%u@9and they rose to their feet, kicked him out of the city, and forced him along until they got to the crest of the large hill upon which their city had been built, in order to toss him down over the edge. %u@3%u@0He, though, having wriggled his way out of their clutches, went his way.%vn~
          %u@3%u@1He went over to Capernaum, a city in Galilee, and was teaching them on the Sabbaths. %u@3%u@2They were time and again amazed at his instruction, since his message was captivating and commanding. %u@3%u@3Now, there was a man in the synagogue who had a vile-and-disgusting, assigned-to-harass%u@ spirit, and he yelled out in a loud voice, %u@3%u@4“Hey! We have no beef with you, Jesus of Nazareth! Have you come to annihilate us? I know who you are—you’re God’s Holy One!” %u@3%u@5Jesus shut him down saying, %r@“%R@S%r@h%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@!%r@” In front of everyone, the demon slammed him to the ground and came out of him, never to harm him again. %u@3%u@6An uproar came upon everyone, and they started saying to each other, “What system of belief%u@ this is, that he commands the vile-and-disgusting spirits in an authoritative and powerful manner, and they depart.” %u@3%u@7News concerning him propagated throughout the entire surrounding area.%vn~
          %u@3%u@8He got up from the synagogue and went to Simon’s (Peter’s) house. Simon’s mother-in-law was running a high fever, and they asked if he could do anything for her. %u@3%u@9He stood over her, rebuked the fever, and it left her. Immediately she got up and started waiting on them. %u@4%u@0While the sun was waning, they brought him everyone and anyone at all who was unwell with various diseases. He kept healing each one of them when he laid his hands on them. %u@4%u@1Demons also were coming out of many, and on their way out were crying out, “You are the Son of God!” He was sternly taking charge over them, forbidding them to speak, since they knew that he was the Christ, the Messiah.%vn~
          %u@4%u@2Now when the day had wound down, he left and went to a place which was uninhabited. The crowd proceeded to look for him and came over to where he was at and kept trying to detain him so that he wouldn’t leave them. %u@4%u@3He told them that he had to deliver the good news of God’s involvement with mankind (God’s kingdom) to the other cities too, since this was the reason he had been sent. %u@4%u@4And he kept preaching this good news in the Judean synagogues.%vn~
%sb~
Luke Chapter 5%hb~
          %u@1Now on one particular day there happened to be a crowd situated in close proximity to him, listening to the word of God; he, though, had taken a place standing on the shoreline of the lake, Lake Gennesaret. %u@2He saw two boats docked on the lake’s shore. Now the fishermen who manned these boats had disembarked and were scrubbing their fishing nets. %u@3But one of them—and this was Simon—was still onboard one of the boats. He asked him to cast the boat out a bit from the shore, and he, having taken a seat in the boat, began to teach the crowd from the boat. %u@4Now as he wrapped up his talk, he said to Simon,%vn~
       %r@“%R@T%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@o%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@u%r@l%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@5Simon answered back, “We’ve been at it all night working and haven’t gotten a thing; but since you said so, I’ll cast the nets.”%vn~
          %u@6And when they’d done this, they entrapped a huge swarm of fish, to the point where it was beginning to break their nets. %u@7They motioned to their partners in the other boat to come help haul the fish in, and they came and filled both boats to their sinking thresholds. %u@8Simon Peter, having witnessed this, fell to his knees before Jesus saying, “Leave me, sir, since I’m a sinful man.” %u@9You see, those surrounding him and all those who were a part of his company were amazed at the take of fish being hauled in. %u@1%u@0In the same way, so were the sons of Zebedee, James and John, Simon’s coworkers. Jesus said to Simon, %r@“%R@D%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@f%r@r%r@a%r@i%r@d%r@:%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@.%r@” %u@1%u@1And after the boats returned to shore, they all left and became his followers.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2While he happened to still be in one of the boats, a man with a full-blown case of leprosy appeared out of nowhere. Seeing Jesus, he fell on his face and begged him, “Sir, should you desire to do so, you can purge the leprosy from me.” %u@1%u@3He stretched out his hand and touched him saying, %r@“%R@I%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@s%r@i%r@r%r@e%r@:%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@r%r@g%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@”%r@ Immediately, the leprosy departed from him. %u@1%u@4He, though, told him sternly and in no uncertain terms to not tell anyone, but instead to go and show himself to the priest and to bring him that which the Old Testament commanded, in order that the evidence be submitted for an official confirmation of the purging of the disease.%vn~
          %u@1%u@5But to an even greater extent, information concerning him spread through and throughout, and huge crowds kept gathering together to listen and to be treated and healed of everything that was dragging them down, physically. %u@1%u@6As far as his own self was concerned, he kept stealing away to various places out in the countryside, alone, praying continually.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7He happened to be teaching one day, and in attendance, paying attention, were Pharisees and instructors in the Law of Moses, who had come from all of the towns of Galilee, Judea, and Jerusalem. There was a supernatural power of the Lord present for him to perform healing. %u@1%u@8Just like that, a group of men showed up carrying a person who was paralyzed on a cot, and they were trying to bring him in and place him in front him, for him to attend to him. %u@1%u@9Since they weren’t able to find any way to bring him in on account of the crowd, they climbed up and got on the rooftop patio, and they lowered him down through the roof itself and put him together with his cot right smack in front of Jesus. %u@2%u@0Seeing their faith, he said, %r@“%R@F%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@2%u@1The designated teachers and the Pharisees proceeded to mull this over,%vn~
      “Just who is this guy, who speaks blasphemies? Who, except for God alone, has the ability to forgive sins?”%vn~
          %u@2%u@2Now Jesus, aware of what they’d been mulling over, responded to them by saying, %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@m%r@u%r@l%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@s%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@s%r@i%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@’%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@G%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@l%r@k%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@’%r@?%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@m%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@o%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %R@P%r@l%r@a%r@n%r@e%r@t%r@ %R@E%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@…%r@“%r@ He addressed the paralytic, %r@“%r@…%R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@e%r@a%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@:%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@2%u@5Immediately and in front of everyone, he got up from that which he’d been seemingly forever lying upon and left for home, glorifying God. %u@2%u@6Everyone became ecstatic and began to glorify God, and they were filled with deep reverence, saying, “We witnessed an incredible miracle.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@7After this he departed. He saw a tax collector named Levi sitting at the tax booth, and he said to him, %r@“%R@B%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@2%u@8He left everything behind, got up, and became one of his followers. %u@2%u@9Levi threw a huge party for him at his house. A large crowd of tax collectors was there and others were there with them seated around the table. %u@3%u@0The Pharisees and their designated teachers started to grumble to his disciples, “Why do you live it up with the tax collectors and sinners?” %u@3%u@1Jesus replied to them, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@l%r@t%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@c%r@t%r@o%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%R@I%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@m%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@r%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@u%r@r%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@f%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@r%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@u%r@m%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@n%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@u%r@r%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@f%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@d%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@3%u@3His disciples said to him, “John fasts day and night, and so do the Pharisees, but your clique parties.” %u@3%u@4Jesus said, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@r%r@o%r@n%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@g%r@a%r@g%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@o%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@y%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@3%u@6He then proceeded to tell them an analogy. %r@“%R@N%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@u%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@ %r@j%r@a%r@c%r@k%r@e%r@t%r@.%r@ %R@S%r@u%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@s%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@a%r@l%r@.%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@7%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@b%r@o%r@d%r@y%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@e%r@s%r@h%r@l%r@y%r@-%r@s%r@q%r@u%r@e%r@e%r@z%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@a%r@p%r@e%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@.%r@ %R@S%r@u%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@f%r@e%r@r%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@r%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@u%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@N%r@o%r@—%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@a%r@p%r@e%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@9%R@P%r@l%r@u%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@b%r@o%r@d%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@;%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@u%r@f%r@f%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@’%r@”%vn~
%sb~
Luke Chapter 6%hb~
          %u@1He happened to be going through a grain field on the Sabbath, and his disciples were plucking off the heads of the stalks and eating them, stripping them of their grain with their hands. %u@2Some of the Pharisees said, “Why are you doing what’s forbidden on the Sabbath?” %u@3Jesus shot back, %r@“%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@D%r@a%r@v%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@u%r@n%r@g%r@r%r@y%r@—%r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@—%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@—%r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@b%r@o%r@d%r@y%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@c%r@e%r@p%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@s%r@—%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@?%r@”%r@ %u@5He proceeded to tell them, %r@“%R@T%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@M%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@b%r@b%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@6On another Sabbath, he introduced himself to those in the synagogue and was teaching there. There was a man there whose right hand was all shriveled up. %u@7The designated teachers and the Pharisees were keeping a close eye on him, to see if he would heal on the Sabbath, so they’d be able to find some violation of the Law of Moses to accuse him of before a judge. %u@8He, though, knew what they were mulling over on the inside and what their intentions were, so he said to the man with the shriveled-up hand, %r@“%R@G%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@”%r@ He got up and stood where he was told to. %u@9Jesus said to them, %r@“%R@Q%r@u%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@:%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@b%r@b%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@g%r@a%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@c%r@c%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@L%r@a%r@w%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@M%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@l%r@i%r@f%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@n%r@i%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@?%r@”%r@ %u@1%u@0He looked around at everyone and said to him, %r@“%R@S%r@t%r@r%r@e%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@.%r@”%r@ He did, and his hand was restored to its original form. %u@1%u@1They, though, had lost their wits filled with rage and began to talk things over with one another, about what they would do to Jesus if they had the chance.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2One day back then, he withdrew to a mountain to pray and was praying continuously to God all night long. %u@1%u@3When daylight came, he called his disciples to gather around, and chose twelve from among them, which twelve are also called “missionaries”: %u@1%u@4Simon, who was renamed Peter, his brother Andrew, James, John, Philip, Bartholomew, %u@1%u@5Matthew, Thomas, James son of Alpheus, Simon the insurrectionist, %u@1%u@6Judas son of James, and Judas Iscariot, the one who became a traitor.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7He descended with them and stopped when the ground leveled off, and there was gathered a large crowd of his disciples, and a great many of the people were from all over Judea, Jerusalem, and Tyre and Sidon, which are on the coast. %u@1%u@8They came to listen to what he had to say and to be healed from their diseases. Those tormented by vile, disgusting spirits were being treated, one after another, %u@1%u@9and all the while the entire crowd sought to be touched by him, since the supernatural power that accompanied him kept on issuing out of him and healing everyone.%vn~
          %u@2%u@0He, for his part, directed his attention to his disciples and proceeded to say,%vn~
%si~
%r@“%R@B%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@o%r@o%r@r%r@,%r@%vp~
%R@S%r@i%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@a%r@c%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@(%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@s%r@)%r@.%r@%vp~
%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%R@B%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@u%r@n%r@g%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@,%r@%vp~
      %R@S%r@i%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@%vn~
%R@B%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@,%r@%vp~
