%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@i%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@u%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%R@A%r@n%r@d%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@l%r@o%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@i%r@f%r@i%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@i%r@f%r@i%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%R@I%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@d%r@e%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@4%R@F%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@m%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@—%R@I%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@o%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@ %R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@o%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@h%r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %R@M%r@y%r@ %R@G%r@l%r@o%r@r%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@l%r@o%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@f%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@i%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@g%r@a%r@n%r@.%r@%vn~
          %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%r@”%R@R%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@e%r@o%r@u%r@s%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@d%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@:%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@.%r@ %R@T%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@t%r@o%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@6%R@I%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@d%r@e%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@p%r@u%r@t%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@a%r@m%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@o%r@c%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
%sb~
John Chapter 18%hb~
          %u@1After saying these things, Jesus, together with his disciples, departed to the other side of Kidron Creek, to where there was a garden, into which he and his disciples entered. %u@2Judas, the one who’ll facilitate his arrest, was familiar with the place, since Jesus and his disciples had gathered there often, %u@3so Judas took the platoon of soldiers tasked with making the arrest and some of the high priests’ and Pharisees’ attendants and gets there with lamps, torches, and weapons. %u@4Jesus, knowing everything that was about to befall him, left the garden and then says to them,%vn~
      %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@?%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@5They replied, “Jesus of Nazareth.”%vn~
      He then says, %r@“%R@I%r@ %r@a%r@m%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@O%r@n%r@e%r@-%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@-%R@O%r@n%r@l%r@y%r@-%R@O%r@n%r@e%r@.%r@”%vn~
      His betrayer Judas stood there among them.%vn~
          %u@6As he said, %r@“%R@I%r@ %r@a%r@m%r@,%r@”%r@ they thereupon retreated backwards and fell on the ground. %u@7So again he asked them,%vn~
      %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@?%r@”%r@%vn~
      So they said, “Jesus of Nazareth.”%vn~
          %u@8Jesus answered, %r@“%R@I%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@.%r@ %R@S%r@o%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@l%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@o%r@w%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@y%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@9He said that in order that the remark, %r@“%r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@r%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@”%r@ would be fulfilled.%vn~
          %u@1%u@0Simon Peter, in possession of a sword, hauled it out and struck the Chief Priest’s slave, slicing off his right ear (the name of the slave was Malchus). %u@1%u@1So Jesus said to Peter, %r@“%R@P%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@w%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@c%r@k%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@s%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@—%r@s%r@h%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@r%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@s%r@i%r@g%r@n%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@?%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@1%u@2So the platoon, the captain, and the Judean attendants arrested Jesus and tied him up. %u@1%u@3They went over to Annas first, as, you see, he was Caiaphas’s father-in-law, who was High Priest that year. %u@1%u@4Now it was Caiaphas who was the one who advised the Judeans that it’s beneficial that one person die on behalf of the folk people.%vn~
          %u@1%u@5Simon Peter and another disciple followed Jesus. Now the Chief Priest’s staff was familiar with that disciple, and he entered into the Chief Priest’s courtyard together with Jesus. %u@1%u@6But Peter stood outside at the doorway. So the other disciple, the one whom the Chief Priest’s staff was familiar with, spoke to the doorman and he let Peter in. %u@1%u@7The doorman’s girl-servant said to Peter,%vn~
      “Aren’t you one of this man’s disciples too?”%vn~
      That fellow said, “No I’m not.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@8Now the servants and attendants made a charcoal fire and were standing there keeping warm. It was cold, you see. Peter was standing there with them keeping warm too.%vn~
          %u@1%u@9The Chief Priest asked Jesus about his disciples and about his teaching. %u@2%u@0Jesus answered, %r@“%R@I%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@o%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@b%r@l%r@i%r@c%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@p%r@e%r@n%r@.%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@s%r@y%r@n%r@a%r@g%r@o%r@g%r@u%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@m%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@y%r@ %R@J%r@u%r@d%r@e%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@m%r@b%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@i%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@i%r@s%r@c%r@l%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@b%r@l%r@i%r@c%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%R@W%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@?%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@k%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@u%r@d%r@i%r@e%r@n%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@o%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@.%r@ %R@C%r@h%r@e%r@c%r@k%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@l%r@f%r@—%r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@l%r@k%r@s%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@2%u@2After he said these things, one of the attendants who was standing there slapped Jesus in the face and said, “Is this any way to address the High Priest?” %u@2%u@3Jesus replied, %r@“%R@I%r@f%r@ %R@I%r@’%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@,%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@c%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@e%r@c%r@i%r@f%r@y%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@r%r@o%r@n%r@g%r@.%r@ %R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@’%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@i%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@r%r@r%r@e%r@c%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@t%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@?%r@” %u@2%u@4Annas sent him tied up to the High Priest Caiaphas.%vn~
          %u@2%u@5Now Simon Peter was standing there keeping warm. They said to him, “You’re one of his disciples too, aren’t you?” That guy put out a denial and said, “No I’m not.” %u@2%u@6One of the high priest’s servants, a relative of the one Peter cut the ear off, then says, “Didn’t I see you in the garden with him?” %u@2%u@7Again Peter denied it, and without delay a rooster crowed.%vn~
          %u@2%u@8They took Jesus away, taking him from Caiaphas to the governor’s palace complex. Now it was early morning the next day, and they didn’t enter the palace complex, so that they wouldn’t be defiled by having contact with Gentiles but instead could partake of the Passover meal. %u@2%u@9So Pilate left the complex and went outside to them, and they conversed:%vn~
      “What charge do you bring against this man?”%vn~
          %u@3%u@0Mustering a response, they told him, “If this guy hadn’t done anything wrong, we wouldn’t have brought him to you.”%vn~
          %u@3%u@1So Pilate told them, “Take him and prosecute him according to your code of law.”%vn~
      The Judeans told him, “It’s forbidden for us to sentence anyone to death.” %u@3%u@2The transferring of the sentencing to the Romans happened in order that Jesus’s statement which he made be fulfilled, in which he indicated what kind of death he was going to die. %u@3%u@3So Pilate went back into the complex, called for Jesus, and told him,%vn~
      “Are you the king of the Jews?”%vn~
          %u@3%u@4Jesus replied, %r@“%R@A%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@o%r@w%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@c%r@c%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@p%r@e%r@a%r@t%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@?%r@”%vn~
          %u@3%u@5Pilate replied, “I’m not a Jew, now, am I? Your own people and the high priests have handed you over to me. What have you done?”%vn~
          %u@3%u@6Jesus answered, %r@“%R@M%r@y%r@ %R@K%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@l%r@d%r@.%r@ %R@H%r@a%r@d%r@ %R@M%r@y%r@ %R@K%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@l%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@e%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@a%r@g%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@c%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@o%r@d%r@y%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@J%r@u%r@d%r@e%r@a%r@n%r@s%r@.%r@ %R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@r%r@e%r@s%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@i%r@m%r@e%r@ %R@M%r@y%r@ %R@K%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@d%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@s%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@’%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@w%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@3%u@7So Pilate said to him, “So you’re not a king?”%vn~
      Jesus replied, %r@“%R@W%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@a%r@y%r@—%R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@.%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@b%r@o%r@r%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@l%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@b%r@l%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@d%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@h%r@u%r@m%r@a%r@n%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@s%r@o%r@n%r@:%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@u%r@l%r@d%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@c%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@p%r@e%r@a%r@k%r@ %r@u%r@s%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@r%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@.%r@ %R@A%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@i%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@p%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@r%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@v%r@o%r@i%r@c%r@e%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@3%u@8Pilate then says, “What is truth?”%vn~
      After saying this, he once again left the complex to go to the Judeans and then tells them, “I find nothing to charge him with. %u@3%u@9Now, by custom I free one person on the Passover, handing him back over to you. So have you decided that I should free the King of the Jews?” %u@4%u@0They yelled out again and again, “Not this guy—Barabbas instead!” (Barabbas was a thug).%vn~
%sb~
John Chapter 19%hb~
          %u@1Then Pilate took Jesus and had him whipped, %u@2plus the soldiers weaved a crown out of thorns and placed it on his head and clothed him in clothing one finds on a nobleman. %u@3They proceeded to go up to him and say again and again, “Pleased to meet you, King of the Jews,” and slap him. %u@4Once more Pilate left the complex and then says to them, “Hey, I’m taking him outside, removing him from the complex, so that you understand that I haven’t found anything to charge him with.” %u@5Jesus came out wearing the crown of thorns and the nobleman’s clothing. He then tells them, “Here he is—the man of the hour.” %u@6When the chief priests and their attendants saw him, they yelled out,%vn~
      “Crucify! Crucify!”%vn~
      Pilate then says, “Take him and crucify him yourselves; the fact is, I haven’t found anything to charge him with.”%vn~
          %u@7The Judeans answered, “We have a code of law, and according to this code he has to die, since he made himself out to be a son of God.”%vn~
          %u@8So when Pilate heard this remark, he feared all the more, %u@9reentered the complex, and then says to Jesus, “Are you out of your mind?”%vn~
      Jesus didn’t reply.%vn~
          %u@1%u@0Pilate then says, “You won’t talk to me? Don’t you know that I have the authority to acquit you or the authority to crucify you?”%vn~
          %u@1%u@1Jesus replied, %r@“%R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@o%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@c%r@e%r@p%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@.%r@ %R@B%r@e%r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@t%r@r%r@a%r@y%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@c%r@i%r@l%r@i%r@t%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@r%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@c%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@o%r@d%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@w%r@o%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@.%r@” %u@1%u@2As a result of this, Pilate proceeded to try to find a way to release him.%vn~
      The Judeans yelled out, “If you set this guy free, you’re not Caesar’s friend. Everything ‘the king’ himself has done is in defiance to Caesar.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@3Pilate heard these words, brought Jesus out, and seated himself upon the judgment seat at a place called the Stone Pavement (which is Gabbatha in Aramaic). %u@1%u@4Now it was around noon on the preparation day which occurs on the day before the Passover. He then says to the Judeans,%vn~
      “Here he is—your king.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@5Those people yelled out, “Away! Away! Crucify him!”%vn~
      Pilate then says, “Shall I crucify your king?”%vn~
      The chief priests replied, “Apart from Caesar we have no king,”%vn~
          %u@1%u@6So he then handed him over to be crucified.%vn~
      They laid hold of Jesus %u@1%u@7and, lugging his own cross, departed for something called Skull Place (which in Aramaic is Golgotha), %u@1%u@8where they crucified him, and two others with him, one here and one there, with Jesus in the middle. %u@1%u@9In addition, Pilate wrote a sign and put it on the cross; on it was written, “Jesus the Nazarene, King of the Jews.” %u@2%u@0It was written in Aramaic, Latin, and Greek, so that many of the Judeans who were near the city where Jesus was crucified could read what was written on it. %u@2%u@1The Judean chief priests proceeded to tell Pilate, “Don’t write ‘The king of the Jews,’ but instead write, ‘This guy said, “I’m the king of the Jews.”’” %u@2%u@2Pilate replied, “What I’ve written, I’ve written.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@3When the soldiers crucified Jesus, they took his clothing, divided them into four parts, one part for each soldier, and they divided up the undergarment. Now the undergarment was seamless, woven in one piece from the top down, %u@2%u@4so they said to one another, “Let’s not rip it into pieces, but we’ll play a game of chance for it instead and one person will win it,” in order that the verse of Scripture be fulfilled:%vn~
%si~
They divvied up my outer garments among themselves%vp~
And they tossed dice for my inner garment%vp~
%si~
So—yes—the soldiers did this.%nn~
          %u@2%u@5Now Jesus’s mother stood there next to Jesus’s cross; so did his mother’s sister, as well as Mary wife of Clopas and Mary Magdalene. %u@2%u@6So Jesus, seeing his mother and the disciple whom he loved standing next to her, close at hand, available should she need anything, then says to his mother, %r@“%R@L%r@a%r@d%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@n%r@.%r@” %u@2%u@7Then he said to the disciple, %r@“%R@T%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@w%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@.%r@” And from that time onwards, the disciple took her into his household as one of his own.%vn~
          %u@2%u@8After these things happened, Jesus saw that everything had already arrived at the finishing point. In order to fulfill the Scriptures, he then says, %r@“%R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@i%r@r%r@s%r@t%r@y%r@.%r@” %u@2%u@9A container full of wine was lying there, so a sponge-full of wine was put on a stick and put to his mouth. %u@3%u@0When he took the wine, Jesus said, %r@“%R@I%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@n%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@e%r@d%r@,%r@” leaned his head to one side and passed away.%vn~
          %u@3%u@1Since it was the day of preparation for the Passover, the Judeans asked Pilate if they could break their bones into tiny pieces and take them away, so that the bodies wouldn’t remain on the crosses on the Sabbath, since that Sabbath was a high day, being the Passover. %u@3%u@2So the soldiers came and fragmented the bones of the first man and the bones of the other man, those crucified with him. %u@3%u@3But when they came for Jesus, as they saw that he’d already died, they didn’t fragment his bones; %u@3%u@4instead one of the solders pierced the side of his rib cage with a spear, and blood and water came out right away. %u@3%u@5One person who had seen this went on record to verify that this did actually happen, and his testimony is trustworthy, and that fellow knows that he’s telling the truth, so that you all too would believe that this happened. %u@3%u@6In fact, these things happened so that the verse of Scripture would be fulfilled, “Not a single one of his bones will be broken,” %u@3%u@7and not only that but another verse which says, “They will look at the one they pierced.”%vn~
          %u@3%u@8After these things happened, Joseph of Arimathea, a disciple of Jesus who but for fear of the Judeans concealed the fact, asked Pilate if he could take Jesus’s body away, and Pilate permitted it. %u@3%u@9And Nicodemus—he who came to him at night—came too bringing a mixture of myrrh and aloes, about 75 lbs. (33 kg.). %u@4%u@0So they took Jesus’s body and wrapped it in fine linen with the aromas, according to the Jewish burial custom.%vn~
          %u@4%u@1Now there was a garden in the place where he was crucified, and in the garden was a new tomb in which no one had ever been laid. %u@4%u@2So on account of the Jewish day of preparation and because the tomb was nearby, they then put Jesus in it.%vn~
%sb~
John Chapter 20%hb~
          %u@1Now on Sunday, while still dark, Mary Magdalene comes early to the tomb and sees that the stone had been taken away from the tomb. %u@2So she runs and comes to Simon Peter and the other disciple whom Jesus had, throughout, a close friendship with and tells them, “They took the Lord from the tomb, and we don’t know where they put him.”%vn~
          %u@3So Peter and the other disciple left and started towards the tomb. %u@4The two were running neck-and-neck, but the other disciple got out ahead of Peter and arrived at the tomb first, %u@5peered in, and sees that the linen cloth lying there, but he didn’t enter, however. %u@6Right behind him, Simon Peter arrives too and entered the tomb and sees the linen cloth lying there %u@7along with the face cloth, which was on his head, and which was not lying with the linen cloth but was folded up separately instead and was in its own spot. %u@8Then the other disciple, the one who arrived at the tomb first, entered, saw what there was to see, and believed; %u@9the fact is, they still had not acquired an experience-based understanding of the verse of Scripture which says that he must arise from the dead. %u@1%u@0So they left once more to go to the other disciples.%vn~
          %u@1%u@1Now Mary stood crying just outside the tomb. As she cried and cried, she peered into the tomb %u@1%u@2and beholds two angels in white sitting there where Jesus’s body was lying, one at his head and one at his feet. %u@1%u@3Those angels tell her,%vn~
      “Lady, why are you crying?”%vn~
      She then says, “They took my Lord away and I don’t know where they put him.” %u@1%u@4After saying these words, she turned around and then sees Jesus standing there, but didn’t know that it was Jesus.%vn~
          %u@1%u@5Jesus then tells her, %r@“%R@L%r@a%r@d%r@y%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@c%r@r%r@y%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@?%r@ %R@W%r@h%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@?%r@”%r@%vn~
      That woman thought that he was the gardener and tells him, “Sir, if you hauled him off, tell me where you put him, and I’ll take him away.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@6Jesus then says, %r@“%R@M%r@a%r@r%r@y%r@!%r@”%r@%vn~
      That woman turned to him and says in Aramaic, “Rabbi!” (i.e. “Teacher”). %vn~
          %u@1%u@7Jesus then says to her, %r@“%R@D%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@u%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@;%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@,%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@c%r@e%r@n%r@d%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@y%r@e%r@t%r@.%r@ %R@N%r@o%r@w%r@,%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@r%r@a%r@d%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@‘%R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@c%r@e%r@n%r@d%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %R@G%r@o%r@d%r@.%r@’%r@” %u@1%u@8Mary Magdalene goes and announces to the disciples, “I have seen the Lord,” and that he told her these things.%vn~
          %u@1%u@9While it was early that Sunday, and while the doors where the disciples were at had been shut tight due to the fear of the Judeans, Jesus came and stood in their midst and tells them, %r@“%R@P%r@e%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@.%r@” %u@2%u@0After saying this, he showed them his hands and the side of his rib cage. So the disciples rejoiced, seeing the Lord. %u@2%u@1Jesus told them once more, %r@“%R@P%r@e%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@.%r@ %R@J%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@,%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@o%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@.%r@” %u@2%u@2After saying this, he breathed on them and tells them, %r@“%R@R%r@e%r@c%r@e%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@H%r@o%r@l%r@y%r@ %R@S%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@2%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@3%R@I%r@f%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@u%r@l%r@t%r@i%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@-%r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@’%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@y%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@s%r@p%r@e%r@c%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@;%r@ %r@i%r@f%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@i%r@r%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@n%r@s%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@p%r@u%r@t%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@2%u@4Now Thomas (i.e. Twin), one of the Twelve, wasn’t with them when Jesus came by. %u@2%u@5So the other disciples proceeded to tell him, “We have seen the Lord.” But he told them, “If I don’t get to see the nail holes in his hands and poke my finger into the holes and reach my hand into his rib cage, there’s no way I’m going to believe it.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@6Eight days later his disciples once again were gathered inside, and Thomas was with them this time. While the doors were shut tight, Jesus then comes, stood in their midst, and says, %r@“%R@P%r@e%r@a%r@c%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@.%r@” %u@2%u@7Then he tells Thomas, %r@“%R@B%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@t%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@r%r@i%r@b%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@g%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@u%r@r%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@f%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@u%r@r%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@s%r@t%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@.%r@” %u@2%u@8In response to it all, Thomas said to him, “My Lord and my God.” %u@2%u@9Jesus then tells him, %r@“%R@B%r@e%r@c%r@a%r@u%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@g%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@o%r@d%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@o%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@-%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@c%r@h%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@o%r@i%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@?%r@ %R@B%r@l%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@o%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@k%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@c%r@i%r@s%r@i%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@l%r@i%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@3%u@0So, yes, Jesus performed many miracles and a variety of them in front of his disciples, ones that aren’t recorded in this book of the Bible. %u@3%u@1But these miracles have been recorded so that you all would acquire faith that Jesus is the Messiah—the Christ—the Son of God, and so that, while faith is being acquired, you would have that special life through the authority vested in him.%vn~
%sb~
John Chapter 21%hb~
          %u@1After these things Jesus manifested himself once more to the disciples at the Sea of Tiberias. Now this is the way he made his appearance: %u@2Simon Peter; Thomas (i.e. “Twin”); Nathanael, who was from Cana, Galilee; the sons of Zebedee; and two of his other disciples were together. %u@3Simon Peter then tells them, “I’m going fishing.” They then say, “We’re coming with you.” They left, boarded the boat they used for fishing, and caught nothing that night.%vn~
          %u@4Now it had already become early morning. Jesus stood on the shore; the disciples however didn’t know it was him. %u@5So Jesus says, %r@“%R@B%r@o%r@y%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@y%r@t%r@h%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@e%r@d%r@i%r@b%r@l%r@e%r@—%r@n%r@a%r@m%r@e%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@—%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@?%r@” They replied, “No.” %u@6So he said, %r@“%R@C%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@o%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@a%r@r%r@b%r@o%r@a%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@s%r@i%r@d%r@e%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@o%r@a%r@t%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@.%r@” So they cast the net and could barely haul it in due to the huge number of fish. %u@7That disciple whom Jesus loved and loved then says to Peter, “It’s the Lord!” Simon Peter, after he heard that it’s the Lord, took off the coat which was wrapped around him (he was naked underneath, you see) and dove into the sea. %u@8But the other disciples came in with the boat, seeing that they were not far from land, no, not far at all, only about 100 yards/90 meters away, dragging the net full of fish.%vn~
          %u@9As they got out onto the dry ground, they see a charcoal fire spread out over the ground and grilled fish laid on top of the fire, plus bread. %u@1%u@0Jesus then tells them, %r@“%R@P%r@u%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@t%r@ %r@j%r@u%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@w%r@.%r@” %u@1%u@1So Simon Peter went over and dragged the net full of enormous fish onto the land, 153 in all. The net didn’t tear, even though there were so many fish.%vn~
          %u@1%u@2Jesus then tells them, %r@“%R@C%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@r%r@e%r@a%r@k%r@f%r@a%r@s%r@t%r@.%r@” Now none of the disciples dared to question who he was—they knew he was the Lord. %u@1%u@3Jesus then comes and takes the bread and passes it out to them, and the grilled fish likewise. %u@1%u@4This is the third time Jesus appeared to the disciples after he was raised from the dead.%vn~
          %u@1%u@5When they finished with breakfast, Jesus then says to Simon Peter, %r@“%R@S%r@i%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@J%r@o%r@h%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@o%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@s%r@e%r@?%r@”%r@%vn~
      He tells him, “Yes, Lord, you know I love you as a close friend does.”%vn~
      He then tells him, %r@“%R@F%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@m%r@b%r@s%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@1%u@6He then says a second time, “Simon son of John, do you love me?”%vn~
      He then tells him, “%R@Y%r@e%r@s%r@,%r@ %R@L%r@o%r@r%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@c%r@l%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
      He then tells him, “Be a shepherd to my sheep.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@7He then says a third time, %r@“%R@S%r@i%r@m%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@s%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@J%r@o%r@h%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@c%r@l%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@e%r@s%r@?%r@”%r@%vn~
      Peter was grieved that he said to him a third time, %r@“%R@D%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@l%r@o%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@c%r@l%r@o%r@s%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@i%r@e%r@n%r@d%r@?%r@” He then says to him, “Lord, you know all things; you understand that I love you as a close friend.”%vn~
      Jesus then says to him, %r@“%R@F%r@e%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@s%r@h%r@e%r@e%r@p%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@1%r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%r@”%R@I%r@’%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@l%r@l%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@-%r@t%r@o%r@-%r@g%r@o%r@o%r@d%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@r%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@—%R@I%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@m%r@:%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@l%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@s%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@s%r@e%r@l%r@f%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@y%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@h%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@i%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@i%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@g%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@.%r@ %R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@ %r@f%r@i%r@n%r@a%r@l%r@l%r@y%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@o%r@l%r@d%r@,%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@s%r@t%r@r%r@e%r@t%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@n%r@d%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@o%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@g%r@e%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@d%r@y%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@c%r@a%r@r%r@r%r@y%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@d%r@o%r@n%r@’%r@t%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@.%r@”%r@ %u@1%u@9He said this signifying and insinuating what sort of death he will glorify God with. After he said this, he then tells him, %r@“%R@F%r@o%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@,%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@2%u@0Peter turns to face and look at the disciple who was following them, the one whom Jesus loved and loved, the person who also was the one leaning against him at the dinner they had and said, “Lord, who’s your betrayer?” %u@2%u@1Looking at this fellow, Peter then says to Jesus, “Lord, now what about this fellow?” %u@2%u@2Jesus then tells him, %r@“%R@I%r@f%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@w%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@m%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@ %r@o%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@a%r@r%r@t%r@h%r@ %r@u%r@n%r@t%r@i%r@l%r@ %R@I%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@c%r@k%r@ %r@a%r@g%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@?%r@ %R@Y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@l%r@l%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@d%r@e%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@.%r@” %u@2%u@3So this statement circulated among the comrades, that that disciple won’t ever die. Now Jesus didn’t tell him that he wouldn’t die, rather, %r@“%R@I%r@f%r@ %R@I%r@ %R@W%R@E%R@R%R@E%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %R@W%R@A%R@N%R@T%r@ %r@h%r@i%r@m%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@m%r@a%r@i%r@n%r@…%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@2%u@4This is the disciple, the one who’s going on record and giving an official account about these things and the one who’s writing this book of the Bible. And we know that his official account is trustworthy.%vn~
          %u@2%u@5Now there’s a lot of other things that Jesus did, so many so that if every detail were to be written down one-by-one, my hunch is that there wouldn’t be enough room in the world to store all the scrolls that would be written.%vn~

Acts%ha~
       Luke writes another long treatise for Theophilus, who may have been his former master, a sequel to his Gospel. He picks up the story as he left off in his Gospel, and by the time he reaches Acts 16:10 the narrative switches from they to we, as Luke joins Paul on his journeys.%nv~
       The book is named Acts of the Apostles, but it might be better named Acts of the Early Church.%nv~
       Luke at times will break into long sentences, like Acts 2:30,31. Of course, this long sentence is a quotation from Peter, and in that passage Luke captures a side of Peter which is unseen in the Gospels. In that spontaneous oration of Acts 2—which is one of the high points of the entire book—Peter follows a train of thought through a few quotations from the Old Testament with remarkable clarity and agility, to the point that even his opponents marveled at his newly-found rhetorical abilities (Acts 4:13). These came from the Holy Spirit which came upon him on Pentecost.%nv~
       More so than the other Gospel writers, Luke’s command of Greek allows him to pepper the text with a word here or there, broadening the meaning with nuanced implications, some of which take an entire half-sentence to convey to the English reader. An example this is in Luke 2:39, where he adds an additional word (and).%nv~
       Luke has a knack for finding imaginative metaphors. For example, in Acts 1:17 he compares Judas’s misfortune of being the one who betrays Jesus to someone who casts lots and loses. In Acts 2:1, the counting of days until Pentecost uses a term commonly used by ship captains as they fill their quota of cargo or tackle or whatnot before setting sail. In Acts 9:1, Paul is “still huffing [lit: breathing] murderous threats at the Lord’s disciples.” Interspersing hyperbole with metaphor, Acts 17:21 says, “Now all Athenians and foreigners who reside in Athens have no time for anything other than talking about or hearing about something novel.”%nv~
       Luke quietly introduces Paul (Saul)—who after Jesus is the most influential figure in Christianity—in Acts 7:58 by showing him in the backdrop of the stoning of Stephen, letting the circumstances describe who Paul was rather than a description itself. Luke uses this introduction to transition from Stephen’s stoning at the end of the seventh chapter into Paul’s zealous persecution at the beginning of the eighth, eventually culminating in Saul’s conversion. In his deft use of indirection, in Acts 12:18, instead of directly saying “…a lot of commotion took place..,” he says instead, “When daylight came, no small amount of commotion took place among the soldiers.”%nv~
       An additional benefit gleaned from Luke’s narrative here is that it sheds light on expressions and idioms used throughout the NT. There are several occurrences of the expression “name of Jesus” where a character is doing this or that in the name of Jesus. The student of the Bible deduces the underlying meaning of the name of Jesus by its preponderance in Acts. Another example is “enter God’s kingdom” (Acts 14:22): the context of this verse indicates that this is an idiom, and one should keep that in mind when Jesus says how difficult it is for a rich man to enter God’s kingdom.%nv~
       In the earlier chapters of Acts, much of the dialog and wording sheds light on certain NT concepts. The fourth chapter specifies what the name of Jesus is; in Acts 4:9, we have captured in writing an incident of testing the Lord, and this expanded understanding of what it is to test the Lord sheds light on other NT verses, in this case for example, Matt. 4:7, 1 Cor. 10:9.%nv~
       To top it off, a pattern emerges in the story line, and it goes like this: a miracle occurs, the miracles draws the undivided attention of those who witness it, as their attention is captured, the message of the Gospel is delivered, and those who hear it are converted. Treats like that are found by those who look for them.%nv~
%sb~
Acts Chapter 1%hb~
          %u@1Indeed now—the previous composition which I drafted about everything, oh Theophilus, about what Jesus proceeded to do and do and teach and teach %u@2up until the day he was taken up into heaven, having left orders with the apostles through the Holy Spirit—apostles whom he had personally hand-picked. %u@3After his suffering, he also appeared to them alive using many demonstrations and proofs, making himself visible to them over the course of forty days and discussing matters related to God’s kingdom. %u@4While they were assembled, he commanded them not to leave Jerusalem for a while, but instead to wait for the Father’s promise (quoting Jesus),%vn~
      %r@“%r@…%R@W%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@’%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@h%r@e%r@a%r@r%r@d%r@ %r@a%r@b%r@o%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@m%r@e%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@5%R@W%r@h%r@i%r@l%r@e%r@—%r@y%r@e%r@s%r@—%R@J%r@o%r@h%r@n%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@p%r@t%r@i%r@z%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@p%r@e%r@o%r@p%r@l%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@y%r@ %r@i%r@m%r@m%r@e%r@r%r@s%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@m%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@w%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@r%r@,%r@ %r@b%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@o%r@u%r@g%r@h%r@,%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@ %r@b%r@a%r@p%r@t%r@i%r@z%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@H%r@o%r@l%r@y%r@ %R@S%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@m%r@a%r@n%r@y%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@y%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@r%r@o%r@m%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@w%r@.%r@”%r@%vn~
          %u@6Indeed now—when they were gathered together, they kept asking him over and over, “Lord, is this the moment in time you’re going to reinstate Israel as its own sovereign nation?”%vn~
          %u@7He told them, %r@“%R@I%r@t%r@’%r@s%r@ %r@n%r@o%r@t%r@ %r@b%r@e%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@g%r@r%r@a%r@n%r@t%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@f%r@o%r@r%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@k%r@n%r@o%r@w%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@e%r@x%r@a%r@c%r@t%r@ %r@d%r@a%r@t%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@r%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@o%r@w%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@i%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@i%r@c%r@h%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@F%r@a%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@e%r@s%r@t%r@a%r@b%r@l%r@i%r@s%r@h%r@e%r@d%r@ %r@u%r@s%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %R@H%r@i%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@w%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@o%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@y%r@.%r@ %r@%%r@u%r@@%r@8%R@B%r@u%r@t%r@ %r@n%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@m%r@i%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@a%r@t%r@—%r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@c%r@e%r@i%r@v%r@e%r@ %r@m%r@i%r@r%r@a%r@c%r@l%r@e%r@-%r@w%r@o%r@r%r@k%r@i%r@n%r@g%r@ %r@p%r@o%r@w%r@e%r@r%r@ %r@w%r@h%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %R@H%r@o%r@l%r@y%r@ %R@S%r@p%r@i%r@r%r@i%r@t%r@ %r@h%r@a%r@s%r@ %r@g%r@o%r@n%r@e%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@c%r@o%r@m%r@e%r@ %r@u%r@p%r@o%r@n%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@y%r@o%r@u%r@ %r@w%r@i%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@a%r@t%r@t%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@t%r@o%r@ %r@m%r@y%r@ %r@t%r@r%r@u%r@t%r@h%r@f%r@u%r@l%r@n%r@e%r@s%r@s%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %R@J%r@e%r@r%r@u%r@s%r@a%r@l%r@e%r@m%r@,%r@ %r@i%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@l%r@l%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %R@J%r@u%r@d%r@e%r@a%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %R@S%r@a%r@m%r@a%r@r%r@i%r@a%r@,%r@ %r@a%r@n%r@d%r@ %r@e%r@l%r@s%r@e%r@w%r@h%r@e%r@r%r@e%r@—%r@e%r@v%r@e%r@n%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@f%r@a%r@r%r@ %r@a%r@s%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@f%r@u%r@r%r@t%r@h%r@e%r@s%r@t%r@ %r@r%r@e%r@a%r@c%r@h%r@e%r@s%r@ %r@o%r@f%r@ %r@t%r@h%r@e%r@ %r@p%r@l%r@a%r@n%r@e%r@t%r@.%r@”%vn~
          %u@9After he said these things, while they were still looking at him he was taken up: a cloud took him away out of their sight. %u@1%u@0As they were staring up into the sky while he was travelling upwards, two men dressed in white appeared out of nowhere and stood next to them, %u@1%u@1and they said, “Gentlemen, fellow Galileans, why are you just standing there looking up into the sky? This Jesus who was taken away from you up into the sky will come in the same manner which you’ve observed him travelling into the sky.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@2They then returned to Jerusalem from what’s known as the Mount of Olives, which is near Jerusalem, about a half-mile/1 km down the road. %u@1%u@3When they entered the city, they went to the top floor of where they were staying, they being Peter, John, James, Andrew, Philip, Thomas, Bartholomew, Matthew, James son of Alphaeus, Simon the Zealot, and Judas son of James. %u@1%u@4All of these fellows were in one accord and single-mindedly sticking to it—not getting side-tracked—in prayer, accompanied by women and by Mary the mother of Jesus and his brothers.%vn~
          %u@1%u@5During the span of time they were up there, Peter stood up in the midst of the comrades (and there was a group consisting of 120 grown men, the figure not including the women, teens, and children) and said, %u@1%u@6”Gentlemen, fellow comrades, the verses in the Bible had to be fulfilled which the Holy Spirit spoke beforehand through David’s mouth about Judas, who became ringleader to those who apprehended Jesus, %u@1%u@7that he was considered to be one of us and that he wound up being the unfortunate one who performed this duty.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@8To recap, that guy used some or all of the payment he received for his wrong-doing and acquired a plot of property with it, and got himself in a head-first direction and killed himself in such a way that his torso ruptured and all of his intestines spilled out. %u@1%u@9This became known to all the inhabitants of Jerusalem, resulting in that plot of land being called Akeldama in their language, which is translated “Plot of Blood,” %vn~
          %u@2%u@0Returning to what Peter said, ”Seeing that the Book of Psalms has recorded in it,%vn~
%si~
“Let his domicile go from occupied to unoccupied,%vp~
And from there on out %vp~
Let there be no one who occupies it%vp~
%si~
“And,%nn~
%si~
“Let someone else assume his leadership position%vp~
%si~
%u@2%u@1”So it has to be one of the men who accompanied us the entire time that the Lord Jesus was acquainted with us, %u@2%u@2starting from John’s baptism up until the day which he was taken from us (namely that he was a witness of his resurrection), in order for one of these men to become one of us.”%nn~
          %u@2%u@3Two candidates were put forward, Joseph who’s called Barsabbas, who’s also known as Justus, and Matthias. %u@2%u@4They prayed and said, “You, Lord, are intimately familiar with the hearts of everyone; point out the one you’ve selected from among these two %u@2%u@5to assume the position of this ministry and apostleship, which Judas usurped for his own purpose.” %u@2%u@6They flipped a coin, and Matthias won the toss, and he was henceforth considered to be an apostle along with the eleven others.%vn~

Acts Chapter 2%hb~
          %u@1When all the days had been checked off until fifty were reached—the Day of Pentecost—everyone was together and on the same page. %u@2From out of the sky a noise suddenly occurred, one which seemed like a violent wind was being swept in, and it filled the entire building in which they were sitting. %u@3Tongues like the tongues of the flames from a fire were seen being distributed to them, and a tongue sat upon each and every one of them, %u@4and every one of them was filled with the Holy Spirit and began to speak in various tongues (other languages) as the Spirit kept on giving them the unction to be uttering in tongues.%vn~
          %u@5Now there were Jews staying in Jerusalem, devout men, who were from every nation across the globe. %u@6So when this sound happened, a bunch of them, confused, gathered together, because each person kept hearing them speaking in his own dialect of his own language. %u@7They were non-stop confused and kept on wondering saying, “Don’t look now—but aren’t all of these folks who are speaking Galileans? %u@8And how is it that each of us can hear what’s being spoken in his own native dialect of his own native language?— %u@9Parthians, Medes, Elamites; those who live in Mesopotamia, Judea and not only there but in Cappadocia, Pontus, the province of Asia, %u@1%u@0Phrygia, and not only there but Pamphylia, Egypt and the parts of Libya around Cyrene; visitors from Rome, %u@1%u@1both Jews and Gentiles who’ve converted to Judaism; Cretans and Arabs—we all hear them in our own languages saying things which magnify God.” %u@1%u@2Now everyone kept on being amazed, confused and perplexed, telling one another, “What in the world’s going on?” %u@1%u@3But others, jeering, kept on saying something to the effect, “They went off and got drunk on sweet wine, the stuff the winos are always drinking.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@4Peter along with the eleven others stood to address the crowd, raised his voice, and announced, “Men, Judeans, and everyone who’s staying in Jerusalem: may you listen to what I have to say and may this become understood to you. %u@1%u@5The fact of the matter is, it’s not what you think, that is that these people are drinking, seeing that it’s only nine in the morning, %u@1%u@6but instead this is what’s spoken through the prophet Joel,%vn~
%si~
%u@1%u@7”’In the Last Days, things will turn out this way,’%vp~
God says:%vp~
‘I’ll pour out My Spirit onto all flesh.%vp~
Your sons and daughters will prophesy,%vp~
Your young men will see visions,%vp~
Your elderly men will dream dreams.%vp~
%u@1%u@8In those days I will pour out My Spirit%vp~
Upon My male and female servants—%vp~
Indeed I will—%vp~
And they will prophesy.%vp~
%u@1%u@9I will grant that wonders occur in the sky above%vp~
And signs upon the earth below:%vp~
Blood, fire, and smoke trails.%vp~
%u@2%u@0The sun will change into darkness%vp~
And the moon into blood%vp~
Prior to the coming%vp~
Of the Great and Marvelous Day of the Lord.%vp~
%u@2%u@1And things will turn out this way:%vp~
All who choose to call for the Lord to act on his behalf%vp~
In the way He is reputed to act%vp~
Will be spared calamity.’%vp~
%si~
          %u@2%u@2”Men, Israelites, listen to what I’m telling you. Jesus of Nazareth was a man who had been appointed by God to act on our behalf, and God performed miracles, wonders, and signs for us through him in your midst, as you all know. %u@2%u@3By the specific determination of God, one which He decided ahead of time, this man was apprehended and taken into custody by bad, out-of-control men, fastened to a cross, and the cross was hoisted up as a form of execution. %u@2%u@4God resurrected this man, having broken the travail of death, on account of the fact that it wasn’t possible for him to be overpowered and constrained by death, %u@2%u@5seeing that in the Scriptures David told him,%vn~
%si~
“Throughout it all, I kept on seeing the Lord ahead of time%vp~
In the area that I was most concerned about%vp~
Because He is right where I need Him%vp~
So that I don’t get rattled.%vp~
%u@2%u@6Because of this, I rejoiced in heart and uttered exultations,%vp~
And, what’s more, my physical well-being%vp~
Will occupy the spot where hope exists,%vp~
%u@2%u@7Because You have not left the essence of my life-being%vp~
In the graveyard,%vp~
Nor will You allow your Holy One to undergo decay.%vp~
%u@2%u@8Having familiarized me with the way of life,%vp~
You will fill me with gladness%vp~
With Your undivided attention.%vp~
%si~
          %u@2%u@9”Men, comrades, it’s appropriate to address you with confidence concerning our patriarch David, to say that he too passed away and was buried, and that his tomb has been right nearby from the day he died up until the present time. %u@3%u@0So being a prophet and knowing that God made an oath and ‘swore to him that from out of the collection of those whom he would sire and their offspring, one of them would sit on his throne,’ %u@3%u@1while seeing into the future, he spoke about the resurrection of Jesus; the fact is,%vn~
%si~
“He has neither been left to the graveyard,%vp~
Nor has his flesh undergone decay%vp~
%si~
%u@3%u@2”God resurrected this Jesus-fellow, of which we all are witnesses, %u@3%u@3and thereupon promoted him to the position of God’s Chief Executive—not only that but having received the promise of the Holy Spirit from the Father, he’s poured out all of this that you see and hear. %u@3%u@4You see, David didn’t ascend into heaven, but it was he specifically who said,%nn~
%si~
“The Lord said to my Lord,%vp~
‘Assume the role of being My right-hand man%vp~
%u@3%u@5Until such time I choose%vp~
To subjugate your enemies in obeisance to you’%vp~
%si~
%u@3%u@6”Let it be known with certainty to the entire Israeli ethnicity-nation that God made him both Lord and Messiah (Christ), this Jesus-fellow whom you crucified.”%nn~
          %u@3%u@7Now, after they heard this, it caused their hearts to melt, and they told Peter and the rest of the apostles, “What should we do about it, men, comrades?” %u@3%u@8Peter told them, “Have a change of heart and of ways and go ahead and have each of you be baptized by the authority of Jesus Christ for the forgiveness of your sins, and you will receive the gift of the Holy Spirit. %u@3%u@9You see, the promise is for you, for your children and for everyone who’s far away—it is just as much given to the one as to the other; in other words, it is for all those whom the Lord God happens to or chooses to summon.” %vn~
          %u@4%u@0He kept on stating a lot of other declarations, and kept on appealing to them summarized by saying, “May you escape from this twisted contemporary Zeitgeist.” %u@4%u@1So those who took to heart and acted upon his message were baptized, and on that day around three-thousand individuals were added. %u@4%u@2They were faithful to keep listening to the apostles’ instruction, to keep having fellowship-dinners together, dinners culminating in a communion memorial, and to keep attending the prayer meetings.%vn~
          %u@4%u@3Now a deep reverence was continually maintained, and many signs and wonders kept on occurring through the apostles. %u@4%u@4Now all of those believing were on the same page in regard to the previously mentioned things and shared everything, %u@4%u@5and properties and possessions kept on being sold, and that which was sold kept on being distributed to every person according to whoever happened to have a need. %vn~
          %u@4%u@6Not only that but day by day they continued to be faithful to be in one accord in the temple, and furthermore they continued to attend the dinners mentioned previously from house to house, sharing food with great joy and simplicity of heart, %u@4%u@7praising God and having favor with the entirety of the folk-people—and the Lord kept adding those being saved day by day while the previously mentioned things were going on.%vn~
%sb~
Acts Chapter 3%hb~
          %u@1Now Peter and John went over to the temple at the Three-in-the-Afternoon-Prayer-Time, %u@2and a certain man who was lame from the time he was born, having to be carried around all time, was there, whom some people day after day kept on placing at the temple gate known as the Beautiful Gate, so that he could beg for handouts from those entering the temple complex. %u@3Seeing that Peter and John were about to go into the temple complex, he asked for a handout. %u@4Peter stared at him, and John joined in with him, and Peter said, “Look at us!” %u@5He proceeded to give heed to them, looking at them and paying attention to them, waiting to—expecting to—get something from them. %u@6Peter said, “I don’t have any cash on me, but I’ll give you what I’ve got: by the authority vested in me by Jesus Christ of Nazareth, get up and walk around!”— %u@7And he grabbed him by his right hand and pulled him up—And immediately his feet and ankles were strengthened and made sturdy— %u@8And with a leap he stood up and started walking around and entered the temple complex together with them, walking around, jumping, and praising God. %u@9All the folk-people saw him walking around and praising God, %u@1%u@0and they recognized him as the same beggar who used to sit where the beggars sit at the temple’s Beautiful Gate, and they were filled with amazement and exhilaration at how things had turned out for him.%vn~
          %u@1%u@1While the lame man was clutching Peter and John, folks everywhere at the colonnade known as Solomon’s Colonnade ran towards them, utterly amazed. %u@1%u@2Seeing this, Peter responded to the crowd, “Men, Israelites, why are you amazed at this? Why are you staring at us as though we enabled him to walk by our own power or piety? %u@1%u@3The God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob—the God of our patriarchal ancestors—glorified His servant Jesus, whom you all had arrested and whom you all rejected in the very presence of Pilate, after that guy delivered a verdict that would have set him free. %u@1%u@4You rejected the holy and righteous one and asked for a homicidal man—a murderer—to be let off the hook and given back to you. %u@1%u@5You killed the Prince of Life, whom God raised from the dead, of which we are witnesses. %u@1%u@6And based on the faith which is derived from Jesus’s authorization to act, this person whom you see and know first-hand—Jesus’s authorization to act strengthened him and made him sturdy, and right in front of you all, the through-him-faith gave him this perfect health which you see. %u@1%u@7Yes indeed comrades, I know that you conducted your lives in a way which is consistent with ignorance, just like your predecessors and ancestors did, %u@1%u@8but the God that made the suffering of His Messiah known ahead of time through the mouth of all the prophets caused these things be fulfilled in this manner.%vn~
          %u@1%u@9”So now, have a change of ways and turn your hearts to the obliteration of your sins, %u@2%u@0in order that episodes of refreshing would issue forth from the Lord’s totally-focused attention, and He would send you the one who’s already been appointed to a position of authority, Christ Jesus, %u@2%u@1whom the spiritual world will most definitely embrace up to the times of the establishment of everything that God has spoken through the mouth of His saints—namely the prophets—from day-one. %u@2%u@2Yes, in the Old Testament Moses said that,%vn~
%si~
“The Lord our God will bring to prominence a prophet%vp~
And send him your way,%vp~
A prophet from among our fellow men—%vp~
One who is like me.%vp~
You shall listen to what comes out of him%vp~
And you shall act in accordance to everything%vp~
That he happens to say to you.%vp~
%u@2%u@3What will happen to any individual%vp~
Who chooses not to listen to that prophet%vp~
Is that he will be absolutely annihilated,%vp~
Never seen or heard from again.%vp~
%si~
          %u@2%u@4”Indeed, all the prophets starting with Samuel, including those who came afterwards, talked about and announced these days that we’re living in. %u@2%u@5You all are the beneficiaries of the prophets and of the covenant which God entered into with our ancestors, saying to Abraham, ‘All of the nationalities of the earth will be blessed by one of your descendants.’ %u@2%u@6God first and foremost brought to prominence his servant and sent him your way blessing you when each person turns away from your evil ways.”%vn~
%sb~
Acts Chapter 4%hb~
          %u@1While they were talking to the folk-people, the priests, the temple guards, and the Sadducees showed up, %u@2exasperated because of them teaching the people and proclaiming Jesus’s resurrection from the dead, %u@3and they arrested them and put them in jail until the next day; you see, it was evening already. %u@4Many of those who heard the message became believers, and the number of men (not including women and children) who believe in Jesus reached five thousand.%vn~
          %u@5Now what happened the next day is that the rulers, the councilmen, and the designated teachers convened in Jerusalem— %u@6and Annas the High Priest was among them, and Caiaphas, John, and Alexander, and any person at all who was born into and, as a result, belonged to the high priests’ caste. %u@7They made them stand in the center for questioning,%vn~
      “By what governmental power have you done this, or who authorized you to do this in their agency?”%vn~
          %u@8Then Peter, filled with the Holy Spirit, told them, “Rulers of the people and councilmen: %u@9If we’re being questioned in court today in reference to a good deed done to a feeble man, namely as to just how exactly this fellow has been pulled out of his miserable condition: %u@1%u@0Let it be known to every one of you and to all of the folk-people of Israel that at the behest of and by the authority of Jesus of Nazareth, whom you all crucified, whom God raised from the dead—by using this delegated authority, this fellow stands before you completely well. %u@1%u@1That is,%vn~
%si~
“The stone treated with contempt by you, the builders%vp~
Has become the principal cornerstone%vp~
%si~
%u@1%u@2”There is no security and protection for our natural and spiritual lives in anyone else; the fact of the matter is, there is no other person of impeccable reputation and of authority among the breadth of the varieties of peoples everywhere that the human race has ever produced and put forward as a candidate of such in whom it is absolutely necessary to be rescued from our deplorable spiritual, mental, and physical condition.”%nn~
          %u@1%u@3Gawking at the boldness and confidence with which Peter and John were speaking, and floored by the fact that the men were uneducated and untrained, they were flabbergasted and began to notice that they had a close connection with Jesus, having been a part of his life and ministry. %u@1%u@4Furthermore, seeing the man standing there in unison with them—the one who had been healed—they couldn’t come up with anything to say against the whole affair. %u@1%u@5Ordering them to leave the council chamber, they huddled together %u@1%u@6saying,%vn~
      “What should we do about these people, since it certainly has become apparent to everyone who’s visiting or living in Jerusalem that a recognizable miracle has occurred through them, and we can’t deny it? %u@1%u@7We can’t let this go on; instead, so that this won’t continue to spread more and more among the folk-people, we’ll threaten them telling them to no longer speak to any person using this authority as the basis for their speaking.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@8They summoned them and ordered them not to teach—not even to utter a peep—acting on the basis of Jesus’s authority. %u@1%u@9Responding to that order Peter and John told them, “You make the call whether God considers heeding you more than heeding Him the right thing to do; %u@2%u@0you see, as far as we’re concerned, we can’t NOT talk about what we’ve seen and heard.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@1After they were threatened, they released them, not being able to figure out a way they could punish them on account of the folk-people, because everyone glorified God over what had happened; %u@2%u@2you see, the man whom this miraculous healing happened to was more than forty years old.%vn~
          %u@2%u@3After they were released, they went to their own particular group of people and reported what the chief priests and the councilmen told them. %u@2%u@4After they heard this, everyone single-mindedly and in unison raised their voices and directed their words towards God and said, “Master, You who made the sky, the earth, the sea, and everything in it, %u@2%u@5who, by means of the Holy Spirit, spoke from the mouth of our ancestor, Your servant David,%vn~
%si~
“Just why, now, did the people%vp~
In all the various nations become insolent?%vp~
The folk-people carefully planned%vp~
Things which are useless, %u@2%u@6for which%vp~
The kings of the land stood nearby in support,%vp~
And the rulers were assembled for the same purpose:%vp~
To oppose the Lord and to oppose His Messiah (Christ).%vp~
%si~
%u@2%u@7”The fact is, they actually were assembled in this city for the purpose of opposing Your holy servant Jesus, whom You singled out to be specially chosen and to be given special, supernatural abilities—they being Herod and Pontius Pilate joined by the Gentiles and the Israeli people— %u@2%u@8to do what Your situational control and Your well-thought-through plan decided ahead of time would happen. %u@2%u@9And now, Lord, take a good, hard look at their threats and grant that Your servant speak Your message time after time with total boldness and confidence, %u@3%u@0while at the same time You supernaturally intervene, the intervention resulting in healings, miracles, and supernatural portents occurring through the authority placed in your holy servant Jesus.”%nn~
          %u@3%u@1After they were done praying, the place they were gathered was shaken, and everyone there was filled with the Holy Spirit and then began to speak God’s message with boldness and confidence once they left and got on with their daily business.%vn~
          %u@3%u@2Now the sizable group of believers was of one heart, mind, and soul, and not a single person was saying that anything that he owned belonged to him exclusively, but instead everything was kept in common between them. %u@3%u@3The apostles kept on putting the account of the resurrection of the Lord Jesus out there by means of tremendous miracles, and tremendous grace (i.e., God’s favor and His willingness to act in their behalf and to act through them) was upon them. %u@3%u@4In fact, not a person among them was in need. You see, those who owned properties or houses and other buildings kept on selling them and selling them and bringing the proceeds of the sales %u@3%u@5to the apostles, placing the proceeds in under their care and ownership. Money, goods, and the like were continuously being distributed to each person in proportion to what a given person happened to need.%vn~
          %u@3%u@6Joseph, whom the apostles called Barnabas (which translated means “the epitome of one who fills the role of assistant, advocate, counselor, and encourager”), a clergyman, Cyprian by birth, %u@3%u@7being the owner of a field, sold it and gave the money to the apostles, putting it in their custody.%vn~
%sb~
Acts Chapter 5%hb~
          %u@1Now a certain man named Ananias sold a piece of property in conjunction with his wife Sapphira %u@2and withheld—appropriated—part of the proceeds, keeping the money for himself (his wife was in on it too) and gave a certain amount to the apostles, placing it under their care and ownership. %u@3Peter told him,%vn~
      “Ananias, how is it that Satan filled your heart causing you to lie in the presence of the Holy Spirit and appropriate some of the sales price from the sale of the property? %u@4While you still had it, wasn’t it yours to keep, and after it was sold, didn’t you have the right to retain control over the proceeds? How did this whole affair get lodged in your heart? You didn’t lie to human beings but to God.”%vn~
          %u@5While Ananias was listening to these words, he dropped dead. An enormous sense of awe and reverence—downright fear—came over all those who were listening. %u@6The older teens and younger men wrapped his body up, carried him out, and buried him.%vn~
          %u@7About three hours went by and his wife came in, unaware of what had happened. %u@8Peter reacted to her entrance,%vn~
      “Tell me: did you sell the property for X amount of dollars?”%vn~
      She said, “Yes, for X dollars.”%vn~
          %u@9Peter said to her, “Why did you two conspire to try to pull a fast one on the Spirit of the Lord? Take a look at the feet of those who buried your husband at the door—and they’re going to carry you out as well.”%vn~
          %u@1%u@0She immediately dropped dead alongside his feet. The older teens and younger men came in, checked that she was dead, and took her and buried her next to her husband. %u@1%u@1A sense of awe and reverence—downright fear—came upon the entire community of believers and upon those who heard what happened. %vn~
          %u@1%u@2Lots of miracles, all kinds of them, occurred among the folk-people. Everyone was on the same page, sharing the same heartfelt passion, meeting in the part of the temple complex called Solomon’s Colonnade. %u@1%u@3As far as everyone else was concerned, no one was daring enough to join them, but apart from that, the people thought they were awesome. %u@1%u@4More and more kept being added to their party, those who believe in the Lord that is, and not only men but women too, %u@1%u@5to the point that they were even bringing out into the streets those with maladies of one sort or another, physical problems that were dragging them down, and placing them upon single-person dining couches and cots, so that when Peter came through he might possibly peer down and check in on any one of them and offer assistance in the form of healing. %u@1%u@6Swaths of people in the vicinity of Jerusalem began to gather, bringing those with maladies and those inflicted by dirty, disgusting spirits, all of whom kept on getting healed or otherwise treated for whatever was wrong with them.%vn~
          %u@1%u@7The High Priest and all those associated with him (those who belong to the Sadducees sect) were stirred to action by a competitive, passionate zeal, %u@1%u@8and they apprehended the apostles and put them in the city jail. %u@1%u@9But some time during the night, an angel unlocked the cell door and lead them out, and said, %u@2%u@0”Go stand in the temple complex and tell all the short messages—the accounts, stories, sayings, and anecdotes—of this new life in Christ, and do this over and over again.” %u@2%u@1Once they heard this, they entered the temple at the crack of dawn and proceeded to teach.%vn~
      Now the chief priest came over while leading his entourage of associates—the Council with all of the councilmen—and they sent word to the city jail to retrieve them. %u@2%u@2But when the attendants got there, they didn’t find that they were in the jail, so they turned around, went back, and reported it, %u@2%u@3saying, “We found that the city jail was firmly locked down and found the prison guards standing at all of their posts at all of the doors. After they opened the door and let us in, we discovered that no one was there.” %vn~
          %u@2%u@4As they heard these words, both the commander of the temple guard and the high priests were perplexed over how this could’ve happened. %u@2%u@5Someone showed up and reported to them, “Check this out—the men whom you put in jail are standing in the temple complex teaching the folk-people.” %u@2%u@6Then the commander with a party of attendants attached to him proceeded to get them again and take them away—but not by employing violent force, since they were wary and fearful of the people, lest they be pelted with stones.%vn~
          %u@2%u@7After they brought them into the council chamber, they were made to stand before the Council. The High Priest questioned them, %u@2%u@8”Didn’t I absolutely and emphatically command you not to teach basing your authority to speak on this person? See here now—Jerusalem’s been filled with your teaching, and you want to blame us and have us assume the guilt and consequences for this man’s death.”%vn~
          %u@2%u@9Peter and the apostles replied, “We must obey God over obeying people. %u@3%u@0God our Father resurrected Jesus, whom you got your grubby hands on and killed, having hung him on a wooden cross-beam. %u@3%u@1God exalted this person, this number-one leader and savior, to the position of chief executive officer, to be His right-hand man, to grant a change of heart and of ways to Israel and a forgiveness of sins. %u@3%u@2You personally are first-hand witnesses of these affairs and of the Holy Spirit whom God gave to those who obey Him.”%vn~
          %u@3%u@3This hit a real sore spot with those who heard this, and they became infuriated and were wanting to kill them. %u@3%u@4A Pharisee named Gamaliel, a teacher of the Law of Moses who was well-respected by all the folk-people, got up in the council and ordered the men out for a short while %u@3%u@5and said to them, “Men, Israelites, stop, take a look at yourselves, and think for a moment about what you’re about to do to these men. %u@3%u@6The fact is, a good while ago, Theudas came to prominence, claiming to be someone special, and four hundred men joined up with him. Everyone who believed in his cause disbanded, and his cause amounted to nothing. %u@3%u@7After this, Judas the Galilean came to prominence during the time that the census was being taken, and he led a group of people away in apostasy. And that guy perished too, and everyone who believed in his cause dispersed.%vn~
          %u@3%u@8”With that in mind, at this point in time I’m telling you to walk away from these men and leave them alone, because if either the intentions themselves or this cause as a whole happens to be man-made, it will be demolished. %u@3%u@9But if it originates from God, you won’t be able to wipe them out—lest it become self-evident that you’re fighting against God.”%vn~
      They were persuaded by him, %u@4%u@0and they summoned the men, beat them, and commanded them not to speak based on Jesus’s authority and set them free. %u@4%u@1They therefore proceeded to go their way rejoicing after facing the Council because they had been deemed worthy to be dishonored on behalf of Jesus’s authority %u@4%u@2and didn’t stop meeting in the temple complex and from house to house every day, teaching and proclaiming the good news—the Gospel—of Christ Jesus.%vn~
%sb~
Acts Chapter 6%hb~
          %u@1Now during this timeframe when the number of disciples was expanding, a complaint originated from the Greek-speaking Jews against the native Israeli Jews, that their widows were being overlooked in the Daily Meal Service. %u@2So the twelve summoned the bulk of the disciples and said, “We’re not happy about neglecting the teaching of God’s word by being restaurant waiters. %u@3Look into the matter, comrades, and come up with seven men from among you that it’s been observed and generally agreed are full of spirit and wisdom, whom we might put in charge of this matter. %u@4We, though, will devote ourselves to prayer and to the ministry of the word of God.”%vn~
          %u@5The reasoning put forth was agreeable in the view of the large group assembled, and Stephen, a man full of faith and the Holy Spirit, Philip, Procorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, and Nicolas, who was a convert to Judaism from Antioch, were chosen. %u@6They stood these men before the apostles, and after they prayed for them, they laid their hands on them. %u@7And the word of God kept on being proclaimed, being received, and producing results, and the number of disciples in Jerusalem continued to grow at a high rate, and a bunch of the priests began to obey by believing in the faith.%vn~
          %u@8Now Stephen, full of grace—God’s favor and His willingness to work through him—and miracle-working capability, began to perform tremendous miracles among the people. %u@9Some people from the synagogue of those who are said to be Freedmen, Cyrenians, Alexandrians, and those from Cilicia and the Roman Province of Asia asserted themselves, arguing with Stephen, %u@1%u@0and didn’t have the strength of words to withstand the wisdom and the spirit with which he continuously spoke. %u@1%u@1Then they got men to claim that, “While he was speaking, we definitely heard him make a blasphemous remark against the Bible and God,” %u@1%u@2and stirred up the folk-people, the councilmen, and the designated teachers and descended on him all of a sudden, apprehended him, and brought him into the Council chamber. %u@1%u@3From there, the phony witnesses produced testimony saying, “This man won’t stop uttering remarks against this Holy Place and the Bible. %u@1%u@4The fact is, we definitely heard him saying that this Jesus-of-Nazareth-guy will destroy this place and alter the traditions which Moses passed down to us.” %u@1%u@5The panel of councilmen fixed their eyes upon him and looked at his face and saw that his countenance was like the countenance of an angel.%vn~
%sb~
Acts Chapter 7%hb~
          %u@1So the high priest said, “Is this so?”%vn~
          %u@2He began to speak and said, “Men, comrades, and patriarchs: listen to me. The God of Glory appeared to our ancestral patriarch Abraham while he was living in Mesopotamia, prior to him getting settled in Harran, %u@3and told him, ‘Leave your homeland and your relatives and go to a country which I will point out to you at some point.’ %u@4He then left the country of Chaldea and settled in Harran. After his father died, from there he relocated to this country, to where we live now, %u@5and he wasn’t given a tract of land in this country, one that he and his descendants would own in perpetuity—not even a tiny plot that would’ve been barely big enough to get by on—And he had been promised that, ‘This country be granted to him, given to him for him to own, he and his descendants—his progeny—after him,’ while not having a son at the time. %u@6Here’s what God had to say to him: ‘This is what’s going to happen: his descendants—his progeny—will be foreigners and outsiders in another country, and those in the other country will enslave them and mistreat them for four hundred years. %u@7And I will judge the nation (i.e. personally intervene and put an end to the evil that they’re doing) who made the decision to enslave you…,’ God said, ‘…and after these things have occurred, they will leave and come back to this place here and continuously offer up worship by attending to an ongoing service of rituals.’%vn~
          %u@8”And He imparted to him a covenant comprised of circumcision. According to this set of instructions, he sired Isaac and circumcised him on the eighth day after his birth, and Isaac did this to Jacob, and Jacob to the twelve patriarchs, the ancestral founders of what would be the twelve tribes of Israel.%vn~
          %u@9”But the patriarchs were jealous of Joseph and handed him over to be put in the custody of some Egyptians; but God was with him, %u@1%u@0and delivered him out of all of his tribulations and gave him favor and wisdom in the presence of the king of Egypt, that is Pharaoh, and he was put in charge over Egypt and over his (Pharoah’s) entire ruling clan and staff. %u@1%u@1Now a famine came out of nowhere and oppressed Egypt and Canaan causing a terrible ordeal, and our eleven patriarchal ancestors weren’t able to find enough food to eat. %u@1%u@2Jacob heard that there was wheat in Egypt and sent out our ancestors as envoys to make the initial contact. %u@1%u@3Second time around Joseph made himself known to his brothers, and Joseph’s birth, lineage, and ethnicity were made apparent to Pharaoh. %u@1%u@4Joseph sent a message and summoned Jacob his father to his side and all the relatives, a total of seventy-five individuals, %u@1%u@5and Jacob went down to Egypt.
